book.info: Apparently the apostle Paul, who alone was qualified to write the deep, high, and rich content of this book. The mention of Timothy and the tone of the fellowship also point to Paul as the author (see also [link]1:1[sup]1[/sup][/link]).
Perhaps A.D. 67, after Paul's release from his first Roman imprisonment, while he was in Miletus ([link]2 Tim. 4:20[/link]).
Perhaps Miletus (see verse in the previous item). The mention of "those from Italy" in [link]13:24[/link] indicates that the book was not written in Rome.
The Hebrew believers, as indicated by the book's content.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]God, having [xref]a[/xref]spoken of old in [note]2[/note]many portions and in many ways to the fathers in the prophets,
verse.note: God has spoken! Praise Him! Without His speaking, God is mysterious. But He has revealed Himself in His speaking. He is no longer mysterious. Now He is the revealed God.[br][br]The emphasis of this book is that God, not man, has spoken. Therefore, it does not identify its writer, nor in any of its quotations from the Old Testament does it mention the speaker's name. According to the concept of this book, the entire Scripture is the speaking of God. Hence, in referring to the Old Testament, this book always says that it is the Holy Spirit's speaking ([link]3:7[/link]; [link]9:8[/link]; [link]10:15-17[/link]).

In the Old Testament, God spoke to the people not once for all and in only one way but in many portions and in many ways: in one portion to the Patriarchs in one way, in another portion through Moses in another way; in one portion through David in one way, in other portions through a number of prophets in several different ways.[br][br]It is most fitting and meaningful that this book, a book of God's speaking, is entitled [i]The Epistle to the Hebrews.[/i] The first Hebrew was Abraham ([link]Gen. 14:13[/link]), the father of all those who contact God by faith ([link]Rom. 4:11-12[/link]). Therefore, God is called "the God of the Hebrews" ([link]Exo. 9:1[/link], [link]13[/link]). The root of the word [i]Hebrew[/i] means [i]to pass over.[/i] It can mean specifically to pass over a river, that is, to pass over from this side of the river to the other side, to pass over from one side to another. Therefore, a Hebrew is a river crosser. Abraham was such a one. From Chaldea, the land of idolatry, which was on the other side of the great river Euphrates, he crossed over to Canaan, the land of the worship of God, which was on this side of the Euphrates ([link]Josh. 24:2-3[/link]). The intention of God's speaking in this book was that the Jews who believed in the Lord but still lingered in Judaism would leave the law and cross over to grace ([link]4:16[/link]; [link]7:18-19[/link]; [link]12:28[/link]; [link]13:9[/link]), that they would leave the old covenant and cross over to the new covenant ([link]8:6-7[/link], [link]13[/link]), and that they would leave the ritualistic service of the Old Testament and cross over to the spiritual reality of the New Testament ([link]8:5[/link]; [link]9:9-14[/link]); that is, that they would leave Judaism and cross over to the church ([link]13:13[/link]; [link]10:25[/link]), that they would leave the earthly things and cross over to the heavenly things ([link]12:18-24[/link]), that they would leave the outer court, where the altar is, and cross over to the Holiest of all, where God is ([link]13:9-10[/link]; [link]10:19-20[/link]), that they would leave the soul and cross over to the spirit ([link]4:12[/link]), and that they would leave the beginning of truth and life and cross over to the maturity of life in the truth ([link]5:11-6:1[/link]). Not only the Jews who believed in the Lord but all who contact God by faith should be such river crossers. This is the purpose of God's speaking in this book.

verse.text: Has at the [note]1[/note]last of these days spoken to us in the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Son, [note]3[/note]whom He appointed [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]Heir of all things, [xref]c[/xref]through whom also He made the [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]universe;
verse.note: A Hebrew expression indicating the end of the dispensation of the law, when Messiah was to be introduced. See [link]Isa. 2:2[/link]; [link]Micah 4:1[/link].

In the Old Testament, God spoke in the prophets, in men borne by His Spirit ([link]2 Pet. 1:21[/link]). In the New Testament, He speaks in the Son, in the person of the Son. The Son is God Himself ([link]v. 8[/link]), God expressed. God the Father is hidden; God the Son is expressed. No one has ever seen God; the Son, as the Word of God ([link]John 1:1[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:13[/link]) and the speaking of God, has declared Him with a full expression, explanation, and definition of Him ([link]John 1:18[/link]).[br][br]The Son is the center, the focus, of this book. In the Godhead He is the effulgence of God's glory and the impress of God's substance. In creation He is (1) the means through which the universe was made ([link]v. 2[/link]); (2) the power that upholds and bears all things ([link]v. 3[/link]); and (3) the Heir appointed to inherit all things. In redemption He accomplished the purification of man's sins and is now sitting on the right hand of God in the heavens ([link]v. 3[/link]).[br][br]This book reveals to us the contrast between the Old Testament and the New Testament. The Old Testament was of the law in letters and forms, of man, earthly, temporary, and by sight and issued in a religion called Judaism. The New Testament is of life, spiritual, heavenly, permanent, and by faith and is focused in a person who is the Son of God.

This short recommendation of the Son in [link]vv. 2-3[/link] unfolds to us both the person and work of the Son. In His person He is the effulgence of God's glory and the impress of God's substance. In His work He created the universe and upholds and bears all things, and made purification of our sins.

I.e., the legal Heir, inheriting all things in God's economy. Since He is not only the Son of God but also the Heir of God, all that God the Father is and has is His possession ([link]John 16:15[/link]). In the past the Son was the Creator ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]10[/link]; [link]John 1:3[/link]; [link]Col. 1:16[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 8:6[/link]); in the present He is the Upholder of all things and the One who bears all things ([link]v. 3[/link]); in the future He will be the Heir, inheriting all things (cf. [link]Rom. 11:36[/link]).

Lit., ages. [i]The ages[/i] is a Jewish expression that means [i]the universe. Ages[/i] here does not refer to the matter of time but to creation (the universe) unfolded in time through successive ages.

verse.text: Who, being the [note]1[/note]effulgence of His glory and the [xref]a[/xref]impress of His substance and [xref]b[/xref]upholding and bearing all things by the [note]2[/note]word of His power, having made [note]3[/note]purification of sins, [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]sat down on the right hand of the [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]Majesty on [note]6[/note]high;
verse.note: The effulgence of God's glory is like the shining or the brightness of the light of the sun. The Son is the shining, the brightness, of the Father's glory. This refers to God's glory. The impress of God's substance is like the impress of a seal. The Son is the expression of what God the Father is. This refers to God's substance.

The Greek word denotes the instant word. The Son upholds and bears all things not by His work but by His instant word, the word of His power. In creation all things came into being through Him as the Word ([link]John 1:1-3[/link]). The universe has been framed by the word of God ([link]11:3[/link]): "He spoke, and it was; He commanded, and it stood" ([link]Psa. 33:9[/link]). In salvation we are saved through His word ([link]John 5:24[/link]; [link]Rom. 10:8[/link], [link]17[/link]). It is through His word that His authority with power is exercised ([link]Matt. 8:8-9[/link]). It is by His word that His healing power is realized ([link]John 4:50-51[/link]). Here, this book says that God speaks in the Son and the Son upholds and bears all things by His word. It is altogether a matter of speaking. When the Lord speaks, everything is in order.

In the Old Testament type the expiation was able only to cover sins ([link]Psa. 32:1[/link]); it was unable to take away sins. So the expiating priests stood daily, offering the same sacrifices ([link]10:11[/link]), and could never sit down. But the Son took away sin ([link]John 1:29[/link]) and accomplished the purification of sins once for all. So He sat down forever ([link]10:10[/link], [link]12[/link]).

This book, having the concept that all positive things are heavenly, points us to the very Christ who is in the heavens. In the Gospels is the Christ who lived on the earth and died on the cross for the accomplishing of redemption. In the Acts is the resurrected and ascended Christ propagated and ministered to men. In Romans is the Christ who is our righteousness for justification and our life for sanctification, transformation, conformation, glorification, and building up. In Galatians is the Christ who enables us to live a life that is versus the law, religion, tradition, and forms. In Philippians is the Christ who is lived out of His members. In Ephesians and Colossians is the Christ who is the life, the content, and the Head of the Body, the church. In 1 and 2 Corinthians is the Christ who is everything in the practical church life. In 1 and 2 Thessalonians is the Christ who is our holiness for His coming back. In 1 and 2 Timothy and Titus is the Christ who is God's economy, enabling us to know how to conduct ourselves in the house of God. In the Epistles of Peter is the Christ who enables us to take God's governmental dealings administered through sufferings. In the Epistles of John is the Christ who is the life and fellowship of the children of God in God's family. In Revelation is the Christ who is walking among the churches in this age, ruling over the world in the kingdom in the coming age, and expressing God in full glory in the new heaven and new earth for eternity. In this book is the present Christ, who is now in the heavens as our Minister ([link]8:2[/link]) and our High Priest ([link]4:14-15[/link]; [link]7:26[/link]), ministering to us the heavenly life, grace, authority, and power and sustaining us to live a heavenly life on earth. He is the Christ now, the Christ today, and the Christ on the throne in the heavens, who is our daily salvation and moment-by-moment supply.
Or, Greatness; denoting God as the greatest One with His dignity.
The high place, the third heaven, the highest place in the universe.

verse.text: Having become as much better than the angels as to have inherited a [note]1[/note]more distinguished name than they.
verse.note: This more distinguished name is "the Son," a name that is fully defined in the succeeding verses.

verse.text: For to which of the angels has He ever said, [xref]a[/xref]"You are My Son; [note]1[/note]this day have I begotten You"? And again, [xref]b[/xref]"I will be a Father to Him, and He will be a Son to Me"?
verse.note: [i]This day[/i] refers to the day of resurrection ([link]Acts 13:33[/link]). This chapter gives us an account of Christ from eternity past to eternity future. He was the very God in eternity past ([link]v. 8[/link]); He was the Creator of the earth and the heavens ([link]vv. 10[/link], [link]2[/link]); He is the Upholder of all things and the One who bears all things ([link]v. 3[/link]); He is the Heir of all things ([link]v. 2[/link]); He was incarnated to accomplish redemption by being crucified ([link]v. 3[/link]); He was begotten as the Son of God in resurrection for the imparting of life to the many sons of God ([link]v. 5[/link]); He is the firstborn Son of God who will come again ([link]v. 6[/link]); He will be the King on the throne with the scepter in the kingdom ([link]vv. 8-9[/link]); and He will remain forever and ever in eternity future ([link]vv. 11-12[/link]).

verse.text: And when He brings again the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Firstborn into the inhabited earth, He says, [xref]b[/xref]"And let all the angels of God worship Him."
verse.note: This verse refers to the Son's second coming. In His first coming He was God's only begotten Son ([link]John 1:14[/link]). Through the process of resurrection the only begotten Son became the Firstborn among many brothers ([link]Rom. 8:29[/link]). Thus, in His second coming He will be the Firstborn.

verse.text: And of the angels He says, [xref]a[/xref]"Who makes His angels [note]1[/note]winds and His ministers a flame of fire";
verse.note: In Greek, the same word as for [i]spirits.[/i] Here it denotes [i]winds,[/i] to match [i]flame[/i] of fire. The angels are like winds and a flame of fire. They are simply creatures, while the Son is the Creator. As creatures, the angels are much inferior to the Son, and as the Creator, the Son is much superior to the angels.

verse.text: But of the Son, [xref]a[/xref]"Your [xref]b[/xref]throne, [note]1[/note]O God, is forever and ever, and the scepter of uprightness is the scepter of Your [xref]c[/xref]kingdom.
verse.note: [i]O God[/i] here and [i]Your God[/i] in [link]v. 9[/link] refer to the Son. Since the Son is God Himself, He is God; therefore, here it says, "O God." Since the Son is also man, God is His God; therefore, in [link]v. 9[/link] it says, "Your God."[br][br]The intention of this book is to show the Hebrew believers that God's salvation is superior to Judaism. In Judaism the boast was in God, angels, Moses, Aaron the high priest, and the Old Testament with its services. Initially, the writer points out that in God's salvation the first superior thing is not only God but God expressed, i.e., God the Son ([link]vv. 2-3[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]8-12[/link]). Then he goes on to unfold that Christ is superior to angels ([link]1:4-2:18[/link]), to Moses ([link]3:1-6[/link]), and to Aaron ([link]4:14-7:28[/link]) and that the new covenant of life made by Him is superior to the old covenant of letters ([link]8:1-10:18[/link]).

verse.text: You have loved righteousness and hated lawlessness; therefore God, [note]1[/note]Your God, has [xref]a[/xref]anointed You with the oil of exultant joy above Your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]partners";
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup][/link].

In God's economy Christ is the One appointed by God to accomplish God's plan, and we are Christ's partners in the divine interest. He was anointed by God, and we share with Him this anointing for the fulfillment of God's purpose. See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: And, [xref]a[/xref]"You in the beginning, [note]1[/note]Lord, laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the works of Your hands;
verse.note: Since the Son is God ([link]v. 8[/link]), He is the eternal Lord, who remains perpetually ([link]v. 11[/link]).

verse.text: They will perish, but You remain perpetually; and they all will become [xref]a[/xref]old like a [xref]b[/xref]garment,
And like a mantle You will roll them up; like a garment they will also be changed; but You are the [xref]a[/xref]same, and Your years will not fail."
But to which of the angels has He ever said, [xref]a[/xref]"Sit at My right hand [note]1[/note]until I set Your enemies as a [xref]b[/xref]footstool for Your feet"?
verse.note: This book stresses the fact that Christ has accomplished everything for God and us, leaving nothing for us to do. His sitting at the right hand of God signifies that His work has been accomplished and that He is resting there, waiting for only one thing — for God to set His enemies as a footstool for His feet. He is sitting there in the heavens waiting for a footstool that He may have complete rest.

verse.text: Are they not all [xref]a[/xref]ministering spirits, sent forth for service for the sake of [note]1[/note]those who are to inherit salvation?
verse.note: The Son is the appointed Heir of all things ([link]v. 2[/link]). We, His believers, are His partners ([link]v. 9[/link]). Thus, we are His joint heirs ([link]Rom. 8:17[/link]), not only inheriting salvation but also inheriting all things with Him ([link]1 Cor. 3:21-22[/link]). Hence, we with Him are joint owners of the universe, while the angels are merely our servants, inferior not only to Him but also to us.[br][br]The Son was appointed to be the Heir. We are saved to be His joint heirs, sharing in His inheritance. The "so great a salvation" mentioned in [link]2:3[/link] is able to save us to such an extent that it brings us into partnership with Him in His appointment. Thus we share in whatever He inherits.[br][br]As the partners of the Son, we are the house of God, the real Bethel, the gate of heaven, where the Son is the heavenly ladder, joining earth to heaven and bringing heaven to earth. On this ladder the angels of God are ascending and descending ([link]Gen. 28:12[/link], [link]16-19[/link]; [link]John 1:51[/link]) as the ministering spirits to serve us, those who inherit so great a salvation. What is spoken of in this book is like the gate of heaven. Here we enjoy Christ as the heavenly One who joins us to heaven and brings heaven to us that we may be a heavenly people, living a heavenly life on earth and inheriting all the heavenly things. How could the Hebrew believers withdraw from this and return to their old religion and boast in the angels? The angels are simply our ministering servants.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore we ought to give heed more abundantly to the things which have been heard lest perhaps we [note]2[/note]drift away.
verse.note: Along with every major point in this book there is a warning. There are five such warnings in the book. Along with the first major point, that Christ is superior to angels, unfolded in [link]1:4-2:18[/link], there is the first warning in [link]vv. 1-4[/link].
Or, drift by them, drift past them.

verse.text: For if the word spoken through [xref]a[/xref]angels proved firm and every transgression and disobedience received a just recompense,

How shall we [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]escape if we have neglected so great a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]salvation, which, having had its beginning in being spoken by the Lord, has been confirmed to us by those who heard,
verse.note: In principle, to escape here is to escape some recompense, as mentioned in [link]v. 2[/link]. If we neglect so great a salvation, it is right and just that we receive a certain recompense.

Salvation here refers back to what is mentioned in [link]1:14[/link]. It is God's full salvation, from the forgiveness of sins to the sharing of the coming kingdom with glory. It refers not only to what Christ has done and will do for us but also to Himself, the One who is able to save us to the uttermost ([link]7:25[/link]). As the Son of God — as God — and as the Son of Man — as man — He is our salvation. His wonderful person plus His splendid work constitute so great a salvation, a salvation that none of us should neglect. Our negligence will cause us to miss this great salvation's (1) most precious part — the enjoying of Christ as our saving life and rest in this age; and (2) most glorious part — the inheriting of Christ's kingdom with glory in the coming age. These two points are fully developed and dealt with in the succeeding chapters of this book.

verse.text: God bearing [xref]a[/xref]witness with [i]them[/i] both by signs and wonders and by various works of power and by [note]1[/note]distributions of the Holy Spirit according to His will?
verse.note: Distributions of the Holy Spirit, which include the Holy Spirit Himself, are the things that the Holy Spirit distributes to those who receive salvation by believing.

verse.text: For [i]it was[/i] not to angels [i]that[/i] He subjected the coming [note]1[/note]inhabited earth, concerning which we speak.
verse.note: I.e., the earth that will become the Lord's kingdom in the next age ([link]Psa. 2:8[/link]; [link]Dan. 2:35[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]).

verse.text: But one has solemnly testified somewhere, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"What is man, that You bring him to mind? Or the son of man, that You care for him?
verse.note: The first man, Adam, created by God in [link]Gen. 1[/link], failed to accomplish God's purpose for man. Psalm 8 then alludes, through prophecy, to another man, a man who would replace the first man and would fulfill God's purpose. This chapter tells us that this other man, the second man, who is Jesus, has come and has accomplished so much for the fulfilling of God's desire in man as revealed in [link]Gen. 1:26[/link], [link]28[/link] and alluded to in [link]Psa. 8:4-8[/link]. Hence, in whatever the first man, Adam, failed, the second man, Christ, succeeded, by replacing the first man.[br][br]This chapter is the fulfillment of the prophecies in [link]Psa. 8[/link] and [link book="Psa."]22[/link] concerning the major steps taken by Christ, as a man, to fulfill God's purpose. In incarnation He partook of human nature ([link]v. 14[/link]). In crucifixion He suffered death for everything ([link]v. 9[/link]) and destroyed the devil ([link]v. 14[/link]). In resurrection He brought forth many sons of God, His brothers, to form the church ([link]vv. 10-12[/link]). In exaltation He was crowned with glory and honor. All these steps are the qualifications that qualify Him to be our High Priest ([link]v. 17[/link]).

verse.text: You have made Him [note]1[/note]a little inferior to the angels; You have crowned Him with glory and honor and have set Him [xref]a[/xref]over the works of Your hands;
verse.note: Or, for a little while inferior. So also in [link]v. 9[/link].

verse.text: You have [xref]a[/xref]subjected all things under His feet." For in subjecting all things to Him, He left nothing unsubject to Him. But now we do not yet see all things subjected to Him,

But we see Jesus, who was made a little [note]1[/note]inferior to the angels because of the suffering of [xref]a[/xref]death, [xref]b[/xref]crowned with [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]glory and honor, so that by the grace of God He might taste death on behalf of [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]everything.
verse.note: In eternity Christ was the Creator, unlimited and omnipresent, but when He became a man in time, He was limited so that one day He could go to the cross to deal with the universal problem — death. In order to suffer death and thus destroy and nullify death, Christ had to become a man and lose His freedom temporarily, for thirty-three and a half years. In that sense, He was inferior to the angels during that period. However, three days after His death He resurrected out of that inferiority and is now much superior to all the angels.

Glory is the splendor related to Jesus' person; honor is the preciousness related to Jesus' worth, value, and dignity, which is related to His position ([link]2 Pet. 1:17[/link]; cf. [link]1 Pet. 2:17[/link]; [link]Rom. 13:7[/link]). In [link]1 Pet. 2:7[/link] the Greek word for [i]preciousness[/i] is the same as that for [i]honor[/i] here.

Or, everyone. The Lord Jesus' redemption was accomplished not only for people but for everything created by God. Thus, God can reconcile all things to Himself through Christ ([link]Col. 1:20[/link]). This is clearly typified by the redemption accomplished through Noah's ark, in which not only eight persons but all living things created by God were saved ([link]Gen. 7:13-23[/link]).

verse.text: For it was fitting for [note]1[/note]Him, [xref]a[/xref]for whom are all things and through whom are all things, in leading [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]many sons into [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]glory, to make the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]Author of their [xref]e[/xref]salvation [note]5[/note][xref]f[/xref]perfect through sufferings.
verse.note: Referring to God, who created all things.
The many sons here are the many brothers in [link]Rom. 8:29[/link] and the many grains in [link]John 12:24[/link].

The last step of God's great salvation is to bring His many sons into glory. [link]Romans 8[/link] tells us that God's work of grace upon us began with His foreknowing, passed through His predestination, calling, and justification, and will end with His glorification ([link]Rom. 8:29-30[/link]). Also, [link]Rom. 8[/link] tells us that the whole creation eagerly awaits the revelation (glorification) of the sons of God, in hope that the creation itself will enter into the freedom of the glory of the children of God ([link]Rom. 8:19-21[/link]). This will be accomplished by the Lord's coming back ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]), at which time we will be manifested with Him in glory ([link]Col. 3:4[/link]); this is our hope ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]). This glorification of the sons of God, as the goal of God's salvation, will last through the millennial kingdom and will be manifested in full in the New Jerusalem for eternity ([link]Rev. 21:11[/link], [link]23[/link]).

Or, Captain, Originator, Inaugurator, Leader, Pioneer. The salvation mentioned in this verse and referred to in [link]v. 3[/link] and [link]1:14[/link] saves us from our fallen state into glory. Jesus, as the Pioneer, the Forerunner ([link]6:20[/link]), took the lead to enter into glory, and we, His followers, are taking the same way to be brought into the same glory, which was ordained by God for us ([link]1 Cor. 2:7[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 2:12[/link]). He cut the way, and we are now taking the way. Hence, He is not only the Savior who saved us from our fallen state but also the Author who, as the Pioneer, entered into glory that we may be brought into the same estate.

To make Jesus perfect was to make Him perfect in terms of qualification. It does not imply that there was any imperfection of virtue or attribute in Jesus, but only that the completing of His experience of human sufferings was needed to make Him fit to become the Author, the Leader, of His followers' salvation.[br][br]As the self-existing and ever-existing God, the Lord Jesus is complete from eternity to eternity. But He needed to be perfected through the processes of incarnation, the partaking of human nature, human living, crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension, that He might be qualified to be God's Christ and our Savior.

verse.text: For both [note]1[/note]He who [xref]a[/xref]sanctifies and those who are being [xref]b[/xref]sanctified are all [note]2[/note]of One, for which cause He is not ashamed to call them [xref]c[/xref]brothers,
verse.note: He who sanctifies is Christ as the firstborn Son of God, and those who are being sanctified are the believers of Christ as the many sons of God. Both the firstborn Son and the many sons of God are born of the same Father God in resurrection ([link]Acts 13:33[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]) and have the same divine life and nature. Hence, He is not ashamed to call them brothers.
Lit., out of. The Sanctifier and the sanctified are all out of one source, one Father.

verse.text: Saying, [xref]a[/xref]"I will [note]1[/note]declare Your name to My brothers; in the midst of the [note]2[/note]church [note]3[/note]I will sing hymns of praise to You."
verse.note: The firstborn Son declared the Father's name to His brothers after He resurrected from the dead, when He met with the Father's many sons ([link]John 20:17[/link], [link]19-23[/link]).
The church is mentioned only twice in this book, here and in [link]12:23[/link]. Here it is referred to as a corporate composition of the many brothers of the firstborn Son of God.

This is the firstborn Son's praising of the Father within the Father's many sons in the church meetings. When we, the many sons of God, meet as the church and praise the Father, the firstborn Son praises the Father in our praising. It is not that He praises the Father apart from us and alone; rather, He praises within us and with us through our praising. In our singing He sings hymns of praise to the Father. If then we do not sing, how can He sing? The more we sing to the Father, the more we enjoy His presence, His moving, His anointing, and His life-imparting within us. Thus we will grow in Him and be brought into His glorification above all.

verse.text: And again, [xref]a[/xref]"I will trust in Him." And again, [xref]b[/xref]"Behold, I and the children whom God has given to Me."

Since therefore the children have shared in [xref]a[/xref]blood and flesh, He also Himself in like manner [xref]b[/xref]partook of the same, that through [xref]c[/xref]death He might [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]destroy him who has the might of [xref]e[/xref]death, that is, the [xref]f[/xref]devil,
verse.note: Or, bring to nought, make of none effect, do away with, abolish, annul, discard. After the devil, the serpent, seduced man into the fall, God promised that the seed of woman would come to bruise the head of the serpent ([link]Gen. 3:15[/link]). In the fullness of the time the Son of God came to become flesh ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:3[/link]) by being born of a virgin ([link]Gal. 4:4[/link]), that He might destroy the devil in man's flesh through His death in the flesh on the cross. (See notes [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in John 3[/link], [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in John 12[/link], and [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 8[/link].) This was to abolish Satan, to bring him to nought. Hallelujah, Satan has been abolished and done away with!

verse.text: And might [note]1[/note]release those who because of the fear of death through all their life were held in slavery.
verse.note: Since the Lord destroyed the devil, who has the might of death, we who were held in slavery through the fear of death have been released by Him. Death reigned over us ([link]Rom. 5:14[/link]), and we were under its slavery, continually fearing death. Since the Lord destroyed the devil and nullified death ([link]2 Tim. 1:10[/link]), we now have no more fear of death and are released from its slavery.

verse.text: For assuredly [i]it is[/i] not to angels [i]that[/i] He [note]1[/note]gives help, but He [note]1[/note]gives help to the seed of Abraham.
verse.note: Jesus has rendered us — human beings, not the angels — help to succor us, to release us from the slavery of death under the devil's might, which is in our nature. He did this by partaking of our nature, in which the devil dwells, and then annulling it on the cross through His all-inclusive death.

verse.text: Hence He should have been [note]1[/note]made [xref]a[/xref]like His brothers in all things that He might become a merciful and faithful [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]High Priest in the [note]3[/note]things [xref]c[/xref]pertaining to God, to make [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]propitiation for the sins of the people.
verse.note: The Son of God was made like us, His brothers, in that He partook of blood and flesh ([link]v. 14[/link]). This was done for two purposes, one negative and the other positive. The negative purpose was to destroy for us the devil, who is in the flesh. The positive purpose is to be our merciful and faithful High Priest who has the human nature, that He may sympathize with us in all things.

As the High Priest, Christ ministers God Himself and the riches of the divine life to us. As the God-man, He is more than fully qualified to be our High Priest. Here, [i]merciful[/i] corresponds with His being a man; [i]faithful[/i] corresponds with His being God.
Lit., things toward God.

Jesus made propitiation for our sins, thereby satisfying the demand of God's righteousness and appeasing the relationship between God and us, that God may be peacefully gracious to us. See note [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 3[/link]. Cf. [link]Luke 18:13[/link] and note 1.

verse.text: For being [xref]a[/xref]tempted in that which He Himself has suffered, He is able to help those who are being tempted.

Therefore, [note]1[/note]holy brothers, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]partakers of a [note]3[/note]heavenly [xref]b[/xref]calling, consider the [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]Apostle and [xref]d[/xref]High Priest of our confession, Jesus,
verse.note: To be holy is to be separated to God for a definite purpose. (See note [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link].) Here, by calling the receivers of the book "holy brothers," the writer intended to remind them that they should not remain common in Judaism but should be separated to God for His purpose.
See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup][/link].

The concept of this book is focused on the heavenly nature of the positive things. First, it points out to us that Christ today is sitting in the heavens ([link]1:3[/link]). He entered into the heavens ([link]9:24[/link]). He passed through the heavens ([link]4:14[/link]) and became higher than the heavens ([link]7:26[/link]). Then this book unfolds to us the heavenly calling ([link]v. 1[/link]), the heavenly gift ([link]6:4[/link]), the heavenly things ([link]8:5[/link]), the heavenly country ([link]11:16[/link]), and the heavenly Jerusalem ([link]12:22[/link]). Also, it tells us that we are enrolled in the heavens ([link]12:23[/link]) and that God warns us today from the heavens ([link]12:25[/link]). All the things in the Old Testament that were held by Judaism were of an earthly nature. In this book the writer's intention was to show the Hebrew Christians the contrast between the heavenly nature of the New Testament and the earthly nature of the Old Testament that they might forsake the earthly things and attach themselves to the heavenly.

The Apostle is the One who was sent to us from God and with God ([link]John 6:46[/link]; [link]8:16[/link], [link]29[/link]). The High Priest is the One who went back to God from us and with us ([link]Eph. 2:6[/link]). As the Apostle, Christ came to us with God to share God with us that we may partake of His divine life, nature, and fullness. As the High Priest, Christ went to God with us to present us to God that we and all our case may be fully cared for by Him. As the Apostle, He is typified by Moses, who came from God to serve the house of God ([link]vv. 2-6[/link]), and as the High Priest, He is typified by Aaron, who went to God with the house of Israel and their cases ([link]4:14-7:28[/link]).

verse.text: Who was faithful to Him who constituted Him, as also [xref]a[/xref]Moses was in all His [xref]b[/xref]house.

For He has been counted worthy of more [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory than Moses, by as much as He who [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]built the house has more [note]1[/note]honor than [note]3[/note]the house.
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

Moses had the human nature, which is fit for God's building, but he did not have the divine nature, which is suitable for being the builder. In contrast, Christ in His humanity is the good material for God's building (the foundation stone — [link]Isa. 28:16[/link]; the cornerstone — [link]Matt. 21:42[/link]; [link]Acts 4:11[/link]; the topstone — [link]Zech. 4:7[/link]; and the living stone that produces us as living stones — [link]1 Pet. 2:4-5[/link]). Moreover, in His divinity He is the Builder.
Lit., it.

verse.text: For every house is built by someone, but He who built all things is God.
And [xref]a[/xref]Moses was faithful in all His house as a [note]1[/note]servant, for a [note]2[/note]testimony of the things to be spoken later;
verse.note: [i]Servant[/i] here is a designation that implies dignity and freedom.
Or, prefigure; a type of the real, typical, and genuine Apostle sent from God.

verse.text: But Christ [i]was faithful[/i] as a Son over His house, whose [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]house we are if indeed we hold fast the boldness and the boast of [xref]b[/xref]hope [xref]c[/xref]firm to the end.
verse.note: In Old Testament times the house of God was the house of Israel ([link]Lev. 22:18[/link]; [link]Num. 12:7[/link]), symbolized by the tabernacle or the temple, which was in Israel's midst ([link]Exo. 25:8[/link]; [link]Ezek. 37:26-27[/link]). Today, the house of God is actually the church ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 4:17[/link]). The children of Israel, as people of God, are a type of us, the New Testament believers ([link]1 Cor. 9:24-10:11[/link]). Their entire history is a prefigure of the church.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Therefore, even as the Holy [xref]a[/xref]Spirit says, [xref]b[/xref]"Today if you hear His voice,
verse.note: This word connects the house of God in [link]v. 6[/link] with the Sabbath rest in [link]4:9[/link], indicating that these two are the same. The house of God is our church life today, our Sabbath rest.

verse.text: Do not harden your hearts as in the provocation, in the day of trial in the wilderness,
Where your fathers [xref]a[/xref]tried [i]Me[/i] by testing [i]Me[/i] and saw My works for forty years.
Therefore I was [xref]a[/xref]displeased with this [xref]b[/xref]generation, and I said, They always [note]1[/note]go astray in their heart, and they have not known My [note]2[/note]ways;
verse.note: Or, err, are deceived.

God's ways are different from His acts. His acts are His activities; His ways are the principles by which He acts. The children of Israel knew only His acts, but Moses knew His ways ([link]Psa. 103:7[/link]).

verse.text: As I swore in My wrath, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]They shall not enter into My rest!"
verse.note: The Hebrew is idiomatic and conveys a strong negative. So also in [link]4:3[/link], [link]5[/link].

verse.text: Beware, brothers, lest perhaps there be in any one of you an evil heart of unbelief in [note]1[/note]falling away from the [xref]a[/xref]living God.
verse.note: Or, turning away, deserting, departing, standing aloof.

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]exhort one another each day, as long as it is called "today," lest any one of you be hardened by the [xref]b[/xref]deceitfulness of sin —
For we have become [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]partners of Christ, if indeed we hold fast the beginning of the assurance [xref]b[/xref]firm to the end —
verse.note: In Greek, the same word as that for [i]partakers[/i] in [link]3:1[/link]; [link]6:4[/link]; and [link]12:8[/link]. In those three places the meaning is that we share in the heavenly calling, the Holy Spirit, and the discipline; thus, the word is rendered [i]partakers.[/i] Here and in [link]1:9[/link] the meaning is that we share with Christ; hence, the word is rendered [i]partners.[/i] We are partakers of heavenly, holy, and spiritual things, sharing in the heavenly calling, the Holy Spirit, and the spiritual discipline. We are partners of Christ, sharing with Him the spiritual anointing ([link]1:9[/link]), as the members share the Spirit with the Head, and sharing with Him the heavenly rest, as Caleb shared with Joshua the rest of the good land ([link]Num. 14:30[/link]).

verse.text: While it is said, [xref]a[/xref]"Today if you hear His voice, do not harden your hearts as in the provocation."
For who [xref]a[/xref]provoked [i]Him[/i] when they heard? Indeed was it [xref]b[/xref]not all who came out of Egypt by [note]1[/note]Moses?
verse.note: Moses brought the children of Israel out of Egypt, but he did not bring them into the good land of Canaan. It was his successor, Joshua, who did this ([link]4:8[/link]).

verse.text: And with whom was He [xref]a[/xref]displeased for forty years? Was it not with those who sinned, whose carcasses [xref]b[/xref]fell in the wilderness?
And to whom did He swear that they should [xref]a[/xref]not enter into His rest, except to the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]disobedient?
verse.note: Or, unpersuadable, obstinate, unbelieving.

verse.text: And we see that they were not able to enter in because of unbelief.
Let us fear therefore, lest, a promise being left of entering into His [note]1[/note]rest, any one of you may [note]2[/note]seem to have [note]3[/note]come short [i]of it.[/i]
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Or, think that he has come too late for it.
See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: For indeed we have had the good news announced to us, even as they also; but the word heard did not profit them, [note]1[/note]not being mixed together with faith in those who heard.
verse.note: Only the Codex Sinaiticus can be rendered in this way. All other ancient MSS read, they [referring to those who heard the word] not being mixed together by faith with those who heard [referring to Caleb and Joshua].

verse.text: For we who have believed enter into the rest, even as He has said, [xref]a[/xref]"As I swore in My wrath, They shall not enter into My rest!" although the works [i]of creation[/i] were completed from the [xref]b[/xref]foundation of the world.
For He has spoken somewhere concerning the seventh day thus, [xref]a[/xref]"And God rested on the seventh day from all His works."
And in this place again, [xref]a[/xref]"They shall not enter into My rest!"
Since therefore it remains that some should enter into it and those who formerly had the good news announced [i]to them[/i] did not enter because of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]disobedience,
verse.note: Or, obstinacy, rebellion, stubbornness, unbelief.

verse.text: He again designates a certain day, today, saying in David after so long a time, even as He has said before, [xref]a[/xref]"Today, if you hear His voice, do not harden your hearts."
For if [note]1[/note]Joshua had brought them into rest, He would not have spoken concerning [note]2[/note]another day after these things.
verse.note: [i]Joshua,[/i] which means [i]Jehovah the Savior[/i] or [i]the salvation of Jehovah[/i] ([link]Num. 13:16[/link]), is a Hebrew name, of which the equivalent in Greek is [i]Jesus.[/i] Hence, Joshua was a type of the Lord Jesus, who brought the people of God into rest.
This "another day" is "today" ([link]3:7[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]15[/link]; [link]4:7[/link]). This is the promised Sabbath rest that remains for us ([link]v. 9[/link]).

verse.text: So then there remains a [note]1[/note]Sabbath rest for the people of God.
verse.note: This Sabbath rest is Christ as our rest, typified by the good land of Canaan ([link]Deut. 12:9[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:8[/link]). Christ is rest to the saints in three stages: (1) in the church age, as the heavenly Christ, the One who rests from His work and sits on the right hand of God in the heavens, He is the rest to us in our spirit ([link]Matt. 11:28-29[/link]); (2) in the millennial kingdom, after Satan is removed from this earth ([link]Rev. 20:1-3[/link]), Christ with the kingdom will be the rest in a fuller way to the overcoming saints, who will be His co-kings ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]), sharing and enjoying His rest; (3) in the new heaven and new earth, after all the enemies, including death, the last enemy, have been made subject to Him ([link]1 Cor. 15:24-27[/link]), Christ, as the all-conquering One, will be the rest in the fullest way to all God's redeemed for eternity. But the Sabbath rest mentioned here and typified by the rest of the good land of Canaan covers only the first two stages of Christ's being our rest; it does not include the third stage. The rest in the first two stages is a prize to His diligent seekers, who not only are redeemed but also have enjoyed Him in a full way, thus becoming the overcomers; whereas the rest in the third stage is not a prize but the full portion allotted to all the redeemed ones. Therefore, in the first two stages, and especially in the second, Christ as our rest is the Sabbath rest mentioned here, the rest that remains for us to seek after and enter into diligently. It is in the second stage of His being our rest that Christ will take possession of the whole earth as His inheritance ([link]Psa. 2:8[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:5-6[/link]), making it His kingdom for a thousand years ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]). All His overcoming followers who seek and enjoy Him as their rest in the first stage will participate in His reign in the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 2:12[/link]). Moreover, they will inherit the earth ([link]Matt. 5:5[/link]; [link]Psa. 37:11[/link]), some having authority over ten cities, some over five ([link]Luke 19:17[/link], [link]19[/link]), and will partake of the joy of their Lord ([link]Matt. 25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]). That will be the kingdom rest, which is typified by the rest of entering into the good land of Canaan. The rest of the good land was the goal of all the children of Israel, who had been redeemed and delivered from Egypt; likewise, the rest of the coming kingdom is the goal of the New Testament believers, who have been redeemed and saved from the world. We are now all on the way toward this goal.[br][br]God's full salvation, which He intended for the children of Israel, included redemption through the passover lamb, the exodus from Egypt, feeding on the heavenly manna, having their thirst quenched by the living water from the cleft rock, and partaking of the good land of Canaan. All the children of Israel shared in the passover lamb, the heavenly manna, and the living water, but only Joshua and Caleb, out of those who shared the exodus from Egypt, entered into the good land and partook of it; all the rest fell in the wilderness ([link]Num. 14:30[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 10:1-11[/link]). Though all were redeemed, only the two overcomers, Joshua and Caleb, received the prize of the good land.[br][br]The passover lamb, the heavenly manna, the living water, and the good land of Canaan are all types of different aspects of Christ. According to what is depicted by the experiences of the children of Israel, not all believers who have been redeemed through Christ will partake of Christ as a prize, as their rest, their satisfaction, in both the church age and the coming kingdom; only those who, after being redeemed, seek Christ diligently will partake of Him in such a way. This is why the apostle Paul, though fully redeemed, was still pursuing toward the goal that he might gain Christ as the prize ([link]Phil. 3:10-14[/link]). In [link]Phil. 3[/link] Paul told us that he had been in Judaism but that for Christ's sake he had given it up ([link]Phil. 3:4-9[/link]). Here, in this book, the writer held the same concept, encouraging the Hebrew believers to forsake Judaism and press toward Christ so that they would not miss the prize.

verse.text: For he who has entered into His rest has himself also rested from his works, as [xref]a[/xref]God did from His own.
Let us therefore be diligent to enter into that rest lest anyone [note]1[/note]fall [note]2[/note]after the same example of [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]disobedience.
verse.note: Since the rest that is covered in this portion of the word is the all-inclusive Christ, to fall from it is to fall from Christ, to be brought to nought from Christ ([link]Gal. 5:4[/link]). In Galatians the danger was that the Galatian believers would drift into the bondage of law from the freedom of grace ([link]Gal. 5:1-4[/link]). Paul advised them to stand fast in the freedom of grace, that is, not to be brought to nought from Christ. Here, in this book, the danger was that the Hebrew believers would not forsake their old religion, which was according to the law, and press on into the enjoyment of Christ as their rest. If they continued to stagger in their old religion, i.e., in Judaism, they would come short of Christ, who was their rest. The writer of this book earnestly encouraged them, as Christ's partners, to press on with Christ and enter into the rest, that they, as His partakers, might enjoy Christ as their rest.
Lit., in.
See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]word of God is [xref]b[/xref]living and operative and sharper than any two-edged [xref]c[/xref]sword, and piercing even to the dividing of [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]soul and [xref]e[/xref]spirit and of joints and marrow, and able to discern the [note]3[/note]thoughts and intentions of the heart.
verse.note: The Greek word denotes the constant word of God. Here it refers to the word in [link]3:7-4:11[/link] that is quoted from the Old Testament (as indicated by the word [i]for[/i] at the beginning of this verse). That word is living, operative, and sharper than a two-edged sword.

According to the Bible, man is a tripartite being — spirit, soul, and body ([link]1 Thes. 5:23[/link]). Here, in this verse, are the joints and marrow — which are parts of the body — and the soul and spirit.[br][br]The foregoing verses describe the children of Israel as falling away from entering into the rest of the good land. With them there were three places: (1) Egypt, from which they were delivered; (2) the wilderness, in which they wandered; and (3) Canaan, into which they entered. Their history in these three places signifies the three stages of their participation in God's full salvation. This is a type of us, the New Testament believers, in our participation in the full salvation of God. In the first stage we receive Christ and are redeemed and delivered from the world. In the second stage we become wanderers in following the Lord; our wandering always takes place in our soul. In the third stage we partake of and enjoy Christ in a full way; this is experienced in our spirit. When we pursue the pleasures of material and sinful things, we are in the world, typified by Egypt. When we wander in our soul, we are in the wilderness. When we enjoy Christ in our spirit, we are in Canaan. When the Israelites were wandering in the wilderness, they were always murmuring, reasoning, and chiding. This surely took place in their soul, not in their spirit. But Caleb and Joshua believed in the word of God, obeyed the Lord, and pressed toward the goal. This surely took place not in their soul but in their spirit. At that time the receivers of this book, the Hebrew believers, were wondering what they should do with their old Hebrew religion. This wondering in their mind was a wandering in their soul, not an experience of Christ in their spirit. So the writer of this book said that the word of God, i.e., what was quoted from the Old Testament, could pierce into their wondering like a sharp two-edged sword and divide their soul from their spirit. As the marrow is concealed deep in the joints, so the spirit is deep in the soul. The dividing of the marrow from the joints requires mainly the breaking of the joints. In the same principle, the dividing of the spirit from the soul requires the breaking of the soul. The Hebrew believers' soul, with its wondering mind, its doubting concerning God's way of salvation, and its considering of its own interests, had to be broken by the living, operative, and piercing word of God that their spirit might be divided from their soul.[br][br]Our soul is our very self ([link]Matt. 16:25[/link]; cf. [link]Luke 9:25[/link]). In following the Lord we must deny our soul, our very self ([link]Matt. 16:24[/link]; [link]Luke 9:23[/link]). Our spirit is the deepest part of our being, a spiritual organ with which we contact God ([link]John 4:24[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:9[/link]). It is in our spirit that we are regenerated ([link]John 3:6[/link]). It is in our spirit that the Holy Spirit dwells and works ([link]Rom. 8:16[/link]). It is in our spirit that we enjoy Christ and His grace ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]; [link]Gal. 6:18[/link]). Hence, the writer of this book advised the Hebrew believers not to stagger in the wandering of their soul, which soul they had to deny, but to press on into their spirit to partake of and enjoy the heavenly Christ that they might participate in the kingdom rest of His reign in the millennium. If they staggered in the wandering of their soul, they would miss God's goal and suffer the loss of the full enjoyment of Christ and the kingdom rest.

Our spirit is the organ with which we contact God ([link]John 4:24[/link]), while our heart is the organ with which we love God ([link]Mark 12:30[/link]). Our spirit contacts, receives, contains, and experiences God. However, this requires that our heart love God first. Our soul is of three parts — mind, will, and emotion; and our spirit too is of three parts — conscience, fellowship, and intuition. Our heart is not separate from our soul and spirit but is a composition of all the parts of our soul, plus the conscience, a part of our spirit. Hence, in our heart is the mind, with the thoughts, and the will, with the intentions. The thoughts affect the intentions, and the intentions carry out the thoughts. The living word of God is able to discern the thoughts in our mind and the intentions in our will. What was quoted from the word of God by the writer in the foregoing verses was able to expose what and where the thoughts and intentions of the Hebrew believers were while they were staggering in the process of their salvation.

verse.text: And there is no creature that is not manifest before Him, but all things are naked and laid bare to the eyes of Him to whom we are [i]to give[/i] our account.

Having therefore a [note]1[/note]great [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]High Priest who has [note]3[/note]passed through the [xref]b[/xref]heavens, Jesus, the [xref]c[/xref]Son of God, let us hold fast the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]confession.
verse.note: I.e., excellent, wonderful, glorious, and most honorable. Christ is great in His person ([link]1:5[/link], [link]8[/link]; [link]2:6[/link]), work ([link]1:3[/link]; [link]2:17[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]14-15[/link], [link]10[/link]; [link]3:5-6[/link]; [link]4:8-9[/link]; [link]Acts 2:24[/link], [link]27[/link]), and attainment ([link]6:20[/link]; [link]9:24[/link]; [link]2:9[/link]).

The Lord Jesus first was sent from God to us through incarnation ([link]2:14[/link]) to be our Apostle ([link]3:1[/link]), our Author, our Leader ([link]2:10[/link]), the One superior to Moses ([link]3:3[/link]), and our real Joshua ([link]4:8[/link]) to bring us, His partners ([link]1:9[/link]; [link]3:14[/link]), into glory and rest ([link]2:10[/link]; [link]4:11[/link]). He then went back from us to God through resurrection and ascension ([link]5:5-6[/link]) to be our High Priest to bear us in the presence of God and to care for all our needs ([link]2:17-18[/link]; [link]4:15[/link]).

Having had the principalities and powers stripped off ([link]Col. 2:15[/link]), having risen from Hades ([link]Acts 2:24[/link], [link]27[/link]), and having passed through the heavens, our High Priest is now sitting on the throne at the right hand of God.
Referring to the faith.

verse.text: For we do not have a High Priest who cannot be touched with the feeling of our weaknesses, but One who has been [xref]a[/xref]tempted in all respects like [i]us, yet[/i] [xref]b[/xref]without sin.
Let us therefore [xref]a[/xref]come forward with boldness to the [note]1[/note]throne of grace that we may receive [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]mercy and find [xref]c[/xref]grace for timely help.
verse.note: Undoubtedly, the throne mentioned here is the throne of God, which is in heaven ([link]Rev. 4:2[/link]). The throne of God is the throne of authority toward all the universe ([link]Dan. 7:9[/link]; [link]Rev. 5:1[/link]). But toward us, the believers, it becomes the throne of grace, signified by the expiation cover (the mercy seat) within the Holy of Holies ([link]Exo. 25:17[/link], [link]21[/link]). This throne is the throne of both God and the Lamb ([link]Rev. 22:1[/link]). How can we come to the throne of God and the Lamb, Christ, in heaven while we still live on earth? The secret is our spirit, referred to in [link]v. 12[/link]. The very Christ who is sitting on the throne in heaven ([link]Rom. 8:34[/link]) is also now in us ([link]Rom. 8:10[/link]), that is, in our spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]), where the habitation of God is ([link]Eph. 2:22[/link]). At Bethel, the house of God, the habitation of God, which is the gate of heaven, Christ is the ladder that joins earth to heaven and brings heaven to earth ([link]Gen. 28:12-17[/link]; [link]John 1:51[/link]). Since today our spirit is the place of God's habitation, it is now the gate of heaven, where Christ is the ladder that joins us, the people on earth, to heaven, and brings heaven to us. Hence, whenever we turn to our spirit, we enter through the gate of heaven and touch the throne of grace in heaven through Christ as the heavenly ladder.

Both God's mercy and God's grace are the expression of His love. When we are in a pitiful condition, first God's mercy reaches us and brings us into a situation in which He is able to favor us with His grace. [link]Luke 15:20-24[/link] tells us that when the father saw the prodigal son returning, he had compassion on him. That was mercy, which expressed the father's love. Then the father clothed him with the best robe and fed him with the fattened calf. That was grace, which again manifested the father's love. God's mercy reaches farther and bridges the gap between us and God's grace.[br][br]God's mercy and grace are always available to us. However, we need to receive and find them by exercising our spirit to come to the throne of grace and contact our High Priest, who is touched with the feeling of all our weaknesses. By this word the writer of this book encouraged the wearied Hebrew believers to receive mercy and find grace for timely help, that they might be set upright ([link]12:12[/link]).

verse.text: For every high priest, being taken from among men, is [xref]a[/xref]established on behalf of men in the things [xref]b[/xref]pertaining to God that he may [xref]c[/xref]offer both [note]1[/note]gifts and [note]1[/note]sacrifices for sins.
verse.note: Gifts are for God's pleasure; sacrifices are for our sins.

verse.text: He is [xref]a[/xref]able to exercise [note]1[/note]compassion toward the [xref]b[/xref]ignorant and [xref]c[/xref]erring since he also is encompassed with [xref]d[/xref]weakness;
verse.note: The Greek here implies a feeling toward the ignorant and erring that is neither too severe nor too tolerant. To exercise compassion is to be moderate or tender in judging their situation. The thought in this verse is a continuation of the thought in [link]4:15[/link]. Though not encompassed with weakness like the high priest taken from among men, Christ as our High Priest was tempted in all respects like us. Hence, being touched with the feeling of our weaknesses, He is able to exercise compassion toward us, the ignorant and erring ones.

verse.text: And because of it, he ought, even as [xref]a[/xref]for the people, so also for himself, to offer for sins.
And [xref]a[/xref]no one takes the honor upon himself, but [i]only[/i] as he is called by God, just as [xref]b[/xref]Aaron also was.

So also Christ did not [note]1[/note]glorify Himself in becoming a [xref]a[/xref]High Priest, but [i]it was[/i] He who said to Him, [xref]b[/xref]"You are My Son; this day have I [note]2[/note]begotten You";
verse.note: In this verse the word [i]glorify[/i] replaces [i]honor[/i] used in the foregoing verse. With the high priest taken from among men, there is only honor, a matter of position. With Christ as the High Priest, there is not only honor but also glory, not only the preciousness of His position but also the splendor of His person. See note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

This refers to Christ's resurrection ([link]Acts 13:33[/link]), which qualifies Him to be our High Priest. For Christ to be our High Priest, He had to partake of our humanity, as mentioned in [link]2:14-18[/link], and enter with this humanity into resurrection. In His humanity He can be touched with the feeling of our weaknesses and be merciful to us ([link]4:15[/link]; [link]2:17[/link]). In resurrection, in His divinity He can do everything for us and be faithful to us ([link]7:24-25[/link]; [link]2:17[/link]).

verse.text: Even as also in another place He says, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"You are a Priest forever according to the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]order of Melchizedek."
verse.note: This refers to the ascension and enthronement of Christ ([link]Psa. 110:1-4[/link]), which are in addition to His resurrection and further qualify Him to be our High Priest ([link]7:26[/link]).

The order of Melchizedek is higher than the order of Aaron. The order of Aaron was for the priesthood that was only in humanity, whereas the order of Melchizedek is for the priesthood that is in both humanity and divinity. This is fully delineated in [link]ch. 7[/link].

verse.text: This One, in the days of His [xref]a[/xref]flesh, having offered up both [xref]b[/xref]petitions and supplications with strong crying and tears to Him who was able to save Him [note]1[/note]out of death and having been heard because of [i]His[/i] piety,
verse.note: [i]Out of death[/i] here does not mean that Christ did not enter into death and suffer death. It means that He resurrected out of death. Before He died, Christ prayed for this, and God answered by raising Him from the dead.

verse.text: Even though He was a Son, learned [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]obedience from the things which He [xref]b[/xref]suffered.
verse.note: God ordained that Christ should die, and Christ obeyed ([link]Phil. 2:8[/link]). He learned this obedience through the suffering of death.

verse.text: And having been [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]perfected, He became to all those who obey Him the [note]2[/note]source of [note]3[/note]eternal [xref]b[/xref]salvation,
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
The Greek word implies the thought of author and cause.
Not everlasting salvation but eternal salvation, of which all the effects, benefits, and issues are of an eternal nature, transcending the conditions and limitations of time.

verse.text: Being [note]1[/note]addressed by God as a [xref]a[/xref]High Priest according to the [xref]b[/xref]order of Melchizedek;
verse.note: This word also conveys the sense of [i]designated, hailed.[/i]

verse.text: Concerning whom we have much to say that is also difficult to interpret since you have become dull of hearing.

For when because of the time you ought to be teachers, you have need again for someone to teach you what the [note]1[/note]rudiments of the [xref]a[/xref]beginning of the [note]2[/note]oracles of God are and have become those who have need of [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]milk and not of solid [xref]c[/xref]food.
verse.note: Or, primary elements.
I.e., divine utterances.

Though this verse mentions [i]teachers[/i] and [i]teach,[/i] it likens the word of God to milk and solid food, which are for nourishment. This corresponds with the Lord's word in [link]Matt. 4:4[/link] and the prophet's word in [link]Jer. 15:16[/link]. Paul and Peter held this same concept concerning the divine word ([link]1 Cor. 3:2[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:2[/link]).

verse.text: For everyone who partakes of [note]1[/note]milk is inexperienced in the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]word of righteousness, for he is an [xref]b[/xref]infant;
verse.note: Milk here refers to the rudiments of the beginning of the oracles of God mentioned in [link]v. 12[/link], whereas the word of righteousness refers to solid food. The good word mentioned in [link]6:5[/link] is the word of the beginning of Christ ([link]6:1[/link]). But the word of righteousness is deeper than the rudiments of the beginning of the oracles of God because it embodies the deeper thought of God's justice and righteousness in His dispensational and governmental dealings with His people. This word is more difficult to discriminate than the word of grace ([link]Acts 14:3[/link]; [link]20:32[/link]) and the word of life ([link]Phil. 2:16[/link]).

verse.text: But solid food is for the [xref]a[/xref]full-grown, who because of practice have their [note]1[/note]faculties exercised for discriminating between both [note]2[/note]good and evil.
verse.note: Or, senses; implying powers of perception that depend not only on our mental capability but also on our spiritual apprehension.

[i]Good and evil[/i] here refers to what is superior in contrast to what is inferior, e.g., the superiority of Christ in contrast to the inferiority of the angels, Moses, and Aaron, or the superiority of the new covenant in contrast to the inferiority of the old covenant. According to the context of this verse, the discriminating mentioned here is similar to discriminating between different foods and has nothing to do with the moral nature of things.

verse.text: Therefore leaving the [note]1[/note]word of the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]beginning of Christ, let us [note]3[/note]be brought on to [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]maturity, not laying again a foundation of [xref]c[/xref]repentance from [xref]d[/xref]dead works and of [xref]e[/xref]faith in God,
verse.note: Or, primary word. The word of the beginning of Christ refers to the six items mentioned in this verse and the next verse, items that constitute the foundation of the Christian life: (1) repentance from dead works, (2) faith in God, (3) the teaching of baptisms, (4) the laying on of hands, (5) the resurrection of the dead, and (6) eternal judgment. These six items form three pairs. The first item of each pair refers to our emergence from a negative situation, and the second speaks of our entering into the positive things. Repentance is a turning away from dead works; faith is the entry into God. Baptisms are separations from and terminations of the negative things; the laying on of hands is the identification and fellowship with the divine things. The resurrection of the dead is the emergence from death; eternal judgment is the entry into eternity and the eternal destiny.

The beginning of Christ includes not only the beginning of the believers' experience of Christ, e.g., the six items enumerated in the latter half of this verse and the next verse, but also the early ministry of Christ, i.e., all His work on earth, recorded in the four Gospels. All saved believers have already experienced, as had the Hebrew believers, the beginning of Christ; henceforth they must pursue unto perfection, unto maturity. The Lord intends to complete this perfecting in His later heavenly ministry, as revealed in this book.

In the experience of our spiritual life, there is always the Lord's doing, on the one side, and our pursuing in cooperation with Him, on the other side. The Lord wants to bring us on to maturity, but we still need to cooperate with Him by being brought on to perfection, to maturity.[br][br]The Lord wants to bring us on, but we must let Him do it. This is our willing cooperation with His gracious work. In order to be brought on to perfection, to maturity, we need to share with Christ in His attainments ([link]1:9[/link]; [link]3:14[/link]), to be diligent to enter into the remaining Sabbath rest ([link]4:9[/link], [link]11[/link]), to come forward to the throne of grace to receive mercy and find grace ([link]4:16[/link]), and to feed on the solid food to enjoy Christ as our High Priest according to the order of Melchizedek ([link]5:9-10[/link], [link]14[/link]).
Or, perfection.

verse.text: Of the teaching of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]baptisms and of the [xref]b[/xref]laying on of hands, of the [xref]c[/xref]resurrection of the dead and of eternal [xref]d[/xref]judgment.
verse.note: [i]Baptisms,[/i] the same word in Greek as for [i]washings[/i] in [link]9:10[/link] and [i]dipping[/i] in [link]Mark 7:4[/link], refers to the washing of the utensils and vessels used for God's service in the tabernacle or temple ([link]Lev. 6:28[/link]) and also, probably, to the washing of the priests ([link]Exo. 30:18-21[/link]; [link]Lev. 16:4[/link]). This matter is, of course, related to the background of the Hebrew believers. However, it is the same in principle as the New Testament baptism — both are the washing away and terminating of the negative things.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]this we will do if God permits.
verse.note: I.e., we will do what is mentioned in [link]v. 1[/link]: be brought on to perfection, to maturity, not laying again the foundation.

verse.text: For it is [note]1[/note]impossible for those who have once been [xref]a[/xref]enlightened and have tasted of the [note]2[/note]heavenly [xref]b[/xref]gift and have become [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]partakers of the Holy [xref]d[/xref]Spirit
verse.note: Those who have once been enlightened and have tasted of the heavenly gift and have become partakers of the Holy Spirit and have tasted the good word of God and the powers of the age to come have already laid the foundation, at the time they believed. If they fall away and turn back, there is no need for them to lay the foundation again ([link]v. 1[/link]); there is only the need to go on, to be brought on to perfection, to maturity. There is no need for them to repeat repentance, for it is impossible for them to renew themselves unto repentance. [link]Verse 1[/link] indicates that it is not needed; [link]v. 4[/link] says that it is not possible; and [link]vv. 7-8[/link] show that it is not right.
The heavenly gift here refers to God's giving of the heavenly things, such as His forgiveness, righteousness, divine life, peace, and joy, at the time we repented and believed in the Lord.

The Holy Spirit is what God in His gospel promised to give man ([link]Gal. 3:14[/link]). God called us from the heavens to the heavenly things that we might become partakers of His Holy Spirit and share in His Holy Spirit. It is by God's Holy Spirit that we can live a heavenly life on earth and partake of the divine holiness. As partakers of the Holy Spirit, we partake of God as our enjoyment. See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: And have [xref]a[/xref]tasted the [xref]b[/xref]good [note]1[/note]word of God and the [note]2[/note]powers of the age [xref]c[/xref]to come,
verse.note: The Greek word denotes the instant word of God. The good word of God here refers to the word of the beginning of Christ, which was mentioned in [link]v. 1[/link] and which was the milk the Hebrew believers tasted when they believed in the Lord. Now they had to go on to the deeper word, the word of righteousness ([link]5:13[/link]), which is concerned not mainly with God's redemption but with the way of His economy, and which was the solid food by which they could reach perfection, maturity ([link]v. 1[/link]).

[i]Powers[/i] here refers to the divine power, and [i]the age to come[/i] refers to the age of the coming kingdom. The divine power of the coming kingdom restores, renews, and revives the things that have become old ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]). At the time of their regeneration ([link]Titus 3:5[/link]) the believers all tasted this divine power and were restored, renewed, and revived.

verse.text: And yet have [note]1[/note]fallen away, to renew [i]themselves[/i] again unto repentance, [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]crucifying again for themselves the Son of God and [note]2[/note]putting [i]Him[/i] to open shame.
verse.note: [i]Fallen away[/i] refers to the fact that the Hebrew Christians deviated from the pure Christian faith by returning to their old, traditional, Judaic religion. In principle, this could be applied to any Christians who fall away from the right track of God's way.

[i]Crucifying[/i] and [i]putting[/i] modify the predicate [i]renew.[/i] To renew unto repentance means to repeat the repentance that has been made already; this is not needed. To do this is to crucify again the Son of God and put Him to open shame.

verse.text: For the earth, which drinks the [note]1[/note]rain which often comes upon it and [note]2[/note]produces vegetation suitable to those for whose sake also it is cultivated, partakes of blessing from God.
verse.note: The rain here refers back to the five categories of good things mentioned in [link]vv. 4-5[/link].

[i]Produces vegetation[/i] is an illustration of being brought on to perfection, to maturity ([link]v. 1[/link]). The believers, as the earth, are tilled for God's sake that they may bring forth Christ, as the vegetation, to perfection, to maturity. By bringing forth Christ they partake of blessing from God.

verse.text: But if it brings forth [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]thorns and thistles, it is [note]2[/note]disapproved and [note]3[/note]near a curse, whose end is to be [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]burned.
verse.note: Strictly, the thorns and thistles here refer to the traditional things of the Hebrew believers' old religion.

Or, rejected, disqualified, counted worthless. The same word is used in [link]1 Cor. 9:27[/link]. If a believer would not be brought on to perfection, to maturity, but rather falls back to the old things, he will be disapproved, be counted worthless, by God.

Once saved, the believers can never be a real curse. However, if they do not go on to grow Christ but rather hold on to things that displease God, they are near the curse of suffering the punishment of God's governmental dealing. (This should be considered with the discipline or chastisement in [link]12:7-8[/link].) Being near a curse is absolutely different from the suffering of eternal perdition, which is the real curse.

The earth could never be burned, but what it brings forth could be burned. The believers could never be burned, but all they bring forth that is not according to God's economy will be burned. The believers are God's cultivated land. Whatever they grow as wood, grass, and stubble will be burned ([link]1 Cor. 3:9[/link], [link]12[/link]).

verse.text: But we are persuaded of better things concerning you, beloved, and [note]1[/note]things which belong to [note]2[/note]salvation, though we speak thus.
verse.note: To bring forth thorns and thistles ([link]v. 8[/link]) is not a thing that belongs to salvation. To give heed to the things that we have heard ([link]2:1[/link]), to be diligent to enter into the promised rest ([link]4:11[/link]), to come forward to the throne of grace ([link]4:16[/link]), and to be brought on to perfection, to maturity ([link]v. 1[/link]) are things that belong to salvation.

Salvation here refers to God's full salvation, the "so great a salvation" mentioned in [link]2:3[/link], including the saving mentioned in [link]7:25[/link], the salvation mentioned in [link]Phil. 1:19[/link] and [link]2:12[/link], and the salvation of the soul mentioned in [link]1 Pet. 1:9[/link]. To be so saved is to be saved from being near the curse of suffering the punishment of God's governmental dealing, mentioned in [link]v. 8[/link].

verse.text: For God is not unrighteous, so as to forget your [xref]a[/xref]work and the love which you have shown toward His [xref]b[/xref]name in having [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]ministered to the saints and in ministering [i]still.[/i]
verse.note: Referring to the ministering of material things to the needy saints.

verse.text: But we desire earnestly that each of you show the same diligence unto the full [xref]a[/xref]assurance of our [xref]b[/xref]hope [xref]c[/xref]until the end,
That you may not be [note]1[/note]sluggish, but [xref]a[/xref]imitators of those who through [xref]b[/xref]faith and long-suffering are [xref]c[/xref]inheriting the promises.
verse.note: Or, dull; as in [link]5:11[/link].

verse.text: For God, when He made the promise to Abraham, since He could swear by no one greater, [xref]a[/xref]swore by Himself,
Saying, [xref]a[/xref]"Surely blessing, I will bless you; and multiplying, I will multiply you."
And thus when [i]Abraham[/i] had patiently [xref]a[/xref]endured, he obtained the [xref]b[/xref]promise.
For men swear by the greater, and for all disputes among them an oath is final for confirmation.
Therefore God, intending to show more abundantly to the [xref]a[/xref]heirs of the promise the [xref]b[/xref]unchangeableness of His counsel, interposed with an oath,

In order that by [note]1[/note]two unchangeable things, in which it was impossible for God to [xref]a[/xref]lie, we may have strong encouragement, we who have [note]2[/note]fled for [note]3[/note]refuge to lay hold of the [xref]b[/xref]hope set before [i]us,[/i]
verse.note: These two things are God's promise and oath ([link]v. 17[/link]).
Lit., fled intensively; implying to flee to a safeguard. Cf. [link]Acts 14:6[/link].

The Lord Jesus entered the heavens, the Holy of Holies within the veil, as mentioned in [link]v. 20[/link], and with Him is the heavenly haven for our refuge, which we can now enter in our spirit ([link]10:19[/link]).

verse.text: Which we have as an [note]1[/note]anchor of the soul, both secure and firm and which [note]2[/note]enters within the veil,
verse.note: [i]Anchor[/i] signifies that we are on a stormy sea and that without the anchor of hope we may shipwreck ([link]1 Tim. 1:19[/link]).

The heavens, into which the Lord Jesus entered, are today the Holy of Holies within the veil. Our hope, as a secure and firm anchor, has entered there, and we may now enter there in our spirit ([link]10:19-20[/link]).

verse.text: Where the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Forerunner, Jesus, has entered for us, having become forever a High Priest according to the [xref]b[/xref]order of Melchizedek.
verse.note: As the Forerunner, the Lord Jesus took the lead to pass through the stormy sea and enter the heavenly haven to be the High Priest for us according to the order of Melchizedek. As such a Forerunner, He is the Author of our salvation ([link]2:10[/link]). As the Forerunner, He cut the way to glory, and as the Author, He entered into glory.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]For this [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Melchizedek, [note]2[/note]king of Salem, priest of the Most High God, who met Abraham returning from the [xref]b[/xref]slaughter of the kings and blessed him,
verse.note: According to the work and ministry of Christ, this book has a turn at this verse, a turn from earth to heaven. To the end of [link]ch. 6[/link], what is revealed is mainly Christ's work on earth, typified by the priesthood of Aaron. That section is the word of foundation. From this verse, Christ's ministry in heaven according to the order of Melchizedek is unveiled. This section is the word of perfection, which shows us how the heavenly Christ ministers in the heavenly tabernacle. His purifying of sins is typified by the work of Aaron, while His sitting down on the right hand of the Majesty on high ([link]1:3[/link]) is according to the order of Melchizedek ([link]Psa. 110:1[/link], [link]4[/link]). His work on the cross on earth, typified by the work of Aaron, affords us forgiveness of sins. His ministry on the throne in heaven ministers to us the overcoming of sin. His cross delivered us out of Egypt; His throne brings us into Canaan. The Hebrew believers participated in His work on the cross. Now they had to press on to enter into the enjoyment of His ministry on the throne.

[i]Melchizedek[/i] means [i]king of[/i] righteousness, and [i]king of Salem[/i] means [i]king of peace[/i] ([link]v. 2[/link]). As the King of righteousness ([link]Isa. 32:1[/link]), Christ made all things right with God and made all things right with one another. Righteousness issues in peace ([link]Isa. 32:17[/link]). As the King of peace ([link]Isa. 9:6[/link]), Christ, through righteousness, brings in peace between God and us, and in such a peace He fulfills the ministry of His priesthood. He is the King who becomes the Priest; thus, His priesthood is kingly, royal ([link]1 Pet. 2:9[/link]).

verse.text: To whom also Abraham apportioned a [xref]a[/xref]tenth part of all; first being interpreted [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]king of righteousness, and then also king of Salem, which is [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]king of peace;
verse.note: At the beginning of this chapter we have the King, and at the end we have the Son of God ([link]v. 28[/link]), indicating that Christ as our High Priest is both kingly and divine.
