His kingship maintains a condition that is full of righteousness and peace that He may minister the processed Triune God to us for our enjoyment; His divinity as the Son of God constitutes Him a High Priest who is living and full of life that He may be able to continue His priesthood perpetually.

verse.text: Being [note]1[/note]without father, without mother, without genealogy; having neither [xref]a[/xref]beginning of days nor [xref]b[/xref]end of life, but likened to the Son of God, abides a priest [xref]c[/xref]perpetually.
verse.note: For all the important persons in Genesis, except Melchizedek, there is a genealogy. In the divine writing, the Holy Spirit sovereignly gave no account of the beginning of Melchizedek's days or of the end of his life, that he might be a proper type of Christ as the eternal One, as our perpetual High Priest. This corresponds with the presentation of the Son of God in the Gospel of John. Being eternal, the Son of God has no genealogy ([link]John 1:1[/link]). But as the Son of Man, Christ does have a genealogy ([link]Matt. 1:1-17[/link]; [link]Luke 3:23-38[/link]).

verse.text: And consider how [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]great this one was, to whom the patriarch Abraham gave a tenth of the choice spoils.
verse.note: The fact that Abraham gave a tenth of the spoils testifies to the greatness of Melchizedek, who is a type of Christ. Christ, as a Priest according to the order of Melchizedek, is greater than the priests of the tribe of Levi, who offered tithes to Melchizedek through their father Abraham ([link]v. 9[/link]), since they were in Abraham's loins when he met Melchizedek ([link]v. 10[/link]).

verse.text: And they of the sons of Levi, who received the priestly service, have a commandment to take [xref]a[/xref]tithes from the people according to the law, that is, from their brothers, though they have come forth from the loins of Abraham.
But he whose genealogy is not counted from them has taken tithes from Abraham and has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blessed him who has the promises.
verse.note: The fact that Melchizedek blessed Abraham testifies again that he is greater than Abraham ([link]v. 7[/link]).

verse.text: But without any dispute the [note]1[/note]lesser is blessed by the [note]2[/note]greater.
verse.note: Or, inferior.
Or, superior, better.

verse.text: And here men, who die, receive tithes; but there, one [xref]a[/xref]of whom it is testified that he [xref]b[/xref]lives.
And, so to speak, through Abraham, [note]1[/note]Levi also, he who receives tithes, has been made to pay tithes,
verse.note: This corresponds with the fact that all the human race sinned in Adam, since all the human race was in the loins of Adam when he sinned ([link]Rom. 5:12[/link]).

verse.text: For he was still in the loins of his father when Melchizedek met him.

If indeed then perfection were through the Levitical priesthood (for under it the people have received the law), what need was there still that a different [note]1[/note]Priest should arise according to the order of [xref]a[/xref]Melchizedek and that He should not be said [i]to be[/i] according to the order of Aaron?
verse.note: This book is focused on the heavenly Christ, and the chief point concerning this Christ is that He is a Priest not according to the order of Aaron but according to the order of Melchizedek. All the other aspects of Christ in the foregoing chapters, such as His being the Son of God, the Son of Man, the Author of salvation, the Apostle, and the real Joshua, are the necessary qualifications for Him to be such a Priest, a Priest who can minister to us whatever we need and save us to the uttermost.

verse.text: For since the [xref]a[/xref]priesthood is [note]1[/note]transferred, of necessity there comes into being a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]transfer of law also.
verse.note: I.e., transferred from the order of Aaron to the order of Melchizedek ([link]v. 11[/link]), from the priestly tribe of Levi to the kingly tribe of Judah ([link]v. 14[/link]), and from men to the Son of God ([link]v. 28[/link]), who is both the only begotten Son and the firstborn Son.
This was a transfer from the law of letters to the law of life, according to which Christ has been appointed a living and perpetual High Priest ([link]v. 16[/link]).

verse.text: For He of whom these things are said [note]1[/note]belongs to a different tribe, from which [xref]a[/xref]no one has attended to the altar.
verse.note: Lit., has partaken of.

verse.text: For it is evident that our Lord has [note]1[/note]risen out of [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Judah, concerning which tribe Moses spoke nothing about priests.
verse.note: The Greek word carries the sense of [i]sprung up, sprouted.[/i]

In the Old Testament, Levi was the tribe of the priests, and Judah was the tribe of the kings. The Lord descended from the tribe of Judah, causing a transfer in the priesthood and combining in one tribe the priesthood and the kingship ([link]Zech. 6:13[/link]), as manifested in Melchizedek, who was both high priest and king ([link]v. 1[/link]).

verse.text: And it is still more abundantly evident since [i]it is[/i] according to the [xref]a[/xref]likeness of Melchizedek [i]that[/i] a different Priest arises,
Who has been appointed not according to the law of a [xref]a[/xref]fleshy commandment but according to the [xref]b[/xref]power of an [note]1[/note]indestructible [xref]c[/xref]life.
verse.note: Or, indissoluble. Christ was appointed the High Priest not according to the powerless letters of law but according to the powerful element of an indestructible life, which nothing can dissolve. This life is endless, being the eternal, divine, uncreated life, and the resurrection life, which passed through the test of death and Hades ([link]Acts 2:24[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:18[/link]). It is by such a life that Christ ministers today as our High Priest. Hence, He is able to save us to the uttermost ([link]v. 25[/link]).

verse.text: For it is testified, "You are a Priest forever according to the [xref]a[/xref]order of Melchizedek."
For there is, on the one hand, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]setting aside of the preceding commandment because of its [xref]b[/xref]weakness and unprofitableness
verse.note: The commandment, or the regulations, of the law concerning the Levitical priesthood was set aside because it was merely in letters and thus was weak. It was not a matter of life but was a dead commandment in letters; thus, it was unprofitable.

verse.text: (For the [xref]a[/xref]law [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]perfected nothing), and, on the other hand, the bringing in [note]2[/note]thereupon of a [note]3[/note]better [xref]c[/xref]hope, through which we [xref]d[/xref]draw near to God.
verse.note: Because of the weakness of man, the law perfected nothing ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]).
Upon the position occupied by the commandment.
This better hope is the priesthood in an indestructible life ([link]v. 16[/link]).

verse.text: And inasmuch as [i]He was[/i] not [i]made a Priest[/i] without the taking of an oath

(For they are appointed priests without the taking of an oath, but He, with the taking of an oath by Him who said to Him, [xref]a[/xref]"The Lord has sworn and will not regret [i]it,[/i] You are a Priest forever"),
By so much Jesus has also become the [note]1[/note]surety of a [xref]a[/xref]better [xref]b[/xref]covenant.
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]a[/i] guarantee, [i]bondsman, sponsor,[/i] and is from the root word meaning [i]a hand into which something is placed as a pledge,[/i] implying that the guarantee, the surety, cannot be unbound. Christ is not only the consummator of the new covenant; He is also the surety, the pledge that everything in that covenant will be fulfilled. That Christ has become the surety of a better covenant is based on the fact that He is the living and perpetual High Priest.

verse.text: And they are appointed priests many in number because death prevents [i]them[/i] from continuing;
But He, because He [xref]a[/xref]abides forever, has His priesthood unalterable.

Hence also He is [xref]a[/xref]able to save [note]1[/note]to the uttermost those who [xref]b[/xref]come forward to God through Him, since He [xref]c[/xref]lives always to [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]intercede for them.
verse.note: Or, completely, entirely, perfectly, to the end, and for eternity.
Christ as our High Priest undertakes our case by interceding for us. He appears before God on our behalf and prays for us that we may be saved and brought fully into God's eternal purpose.

verse.text: For such a [xref]a[/xref]High Priest was also fitting to us, holy, [xref]b[/xref]guileless, undefiled, separated from sinners and having become [note]1[/note]higher than the [xref]c[/xref]heavens,
verse.note: In His ascension Christ passed through the heavens ([link]4:14[/link]), so that now He not only is in heaven ([link]9:24[/link]) but also is higher than the heavens, far above all the heavens ([link]Eph. 4:10[/link]).

verse.text: Who does not have daily need, as the high priests [i]do,[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]offer up sacrifices first for his [xref]b[/xref]own sins and then for those of the people; for this He did [xref]c[/xref]once for all when He [xref]d[/xref]offered up Himself.

For the law establishes men as high priests who have [xref]a[/xref]weakness, but the word of the oath, which [i]was[/i] after the law, [i]establishes[/i] the [xref]b[/xref]Son, [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]perfected forever.
verse.note: [i]Perfected[/i] means [i]brought to an end by being completed,[/i] implying to be made qualified. The Son of God here must be not just the only begotten Son but also the firstborn Son, who has been perfected forever through His incarnation, human living, death, and resurrection. Now He is completely perfected, equipped, and qualified to be our divine High Priest.

verse.text: Now in the things which are being said the chief point [i]is this:[/i] We have such a [xref]a[/xref]High Priest, who sat down on the [xref]b[/xref]right hand of the [xref]c[/xref]throne of the [xref]d[/xref]Majesty in the [note]1[/note]heavens,
verse.note: Christ, as the High Priest in the heavens, brings us into heaven, from the earthly outer court into the heavenly Holy of Holies, which is joined to our spirit by Him as the heavenly ladder ([link]Gen. 28:12[/link]; [link]John 1:51[/link]).

verse.text: A [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Minister of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]holy places, even of the true tabernacle, which the Lord pitched, not man.
verse.note: One who ministers as a priest. As a minister of the true (heavenly) tabernacle, Christ ministers heaven (which is not only a place but also a condition of life) into us that we may have the heavenly life and power to live a heavenly life on earth, as He did while He was here.

The Greek word for [i]holy places,[/i] used as a noun, is plural here. It refers to all the holy places in the tabernacle; strictly, it refers to the Holy of Holies, the holiest of all the holy places ([link]9:8[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]25[/link]; [link]10:19[/link]; [link]13:11[/link]).

verse.text: For every high priest is established for the [xref]a[/xref]offering of both [note]1[/note]gifts and sacrifices; hence it is necessary that this One also have something which He may [xref]b[/xref]offer.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: Now then if He were on earth, He would not be a Priest at all, there being those who offer the gifts according to the law,

Who serve the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]example and [xref]b[/xref]shadow of the heavenly things, even as Moses was divinely instructed when he was about to complete the tabernacle; for, [xref]c[/xref]"See," He said, "that you make all things according to the pattern that was shown to you in the mountain."
verse.note: Or, copy, representation.

verse.text: But now He has obtained a more excellent [note]1[/note]ministry inasmuch as He is also the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Mediator of a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]better [xref]c[/xref]covenant, which has been [note]4[/note]enacted upon [note]5[/note]better [xref]d[/xref]promises.
verse.note: Referring to the ministry of a priest; derived from the same Greek word as [i]minister[/i] in [link]v. 2[/link].
In His heavenly ministry Christ, as the Mediator, is the Executor of the new covenant, the new testament, which He bequeathed to us by His death.

This better covenant not only was enacted upon better promises of a better law, the inner law of life ([link]vv. 10-12[/link]), but also was consummated with Christ's better sacrifices ([link]9:23[/link]), which accomplished for us an eternal redemption ([link]9:12[/link]), and the better blood of Christ, which purifies our conscience ([link]9:14[/link]). Even more, the High Priest of this better covenant, the eternal Son of the living God, ministers with a more excellent ministry ([link]v. 6[/link]) and in the greater and more perfect tabernacle ([link]9:11[/link]).
Just as the old covenant was the old law enacted by God, so the new covenant is the new law enacted by God, as mentioned in [link]vv. 10-12[/link].

The better promises are given in [link]Jer. 31:31-34[/link] and are quoted in [link book="Heb." chapter="8"]vv. 8-12[/link] of this chapter and [link chapter="10"]vv. 16-17[/link] of [link]ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: For if that [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]first [i]covenant[/i] had been faultless, no [note]2[/note]place would have been [xref]b[/xref]sought for a [note]1[/note]second.
verse.note: The first covenant is the old covenant, and the second is the new covenant.
Or, space; metaphorically, occasion, condition.

verse.text: For finding fault with them He says, [xref]a[/xref]"Behold, the days are coming, says the Lord, and I will consummate a [xref]b[/xref]new covenant upon the house of Israel and upon the house of Judah,

Not according to the covenant which I made with their fathers in the day when I took them by their hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt, because they did not continue in My covenant, and I disregarded them, says the Lord.

For [xref]a[/xref]this is the covenant which I will covenant with the house of Israel after those days, says the Lord: I will impart My [note]1[/note]laws into their [note]2[/note]mind, and on their hearts I will [note]3[/note]inscribe them; and [note]4[/note]I will be God to them, and [note]5[/note]they will be a people to Me.
verse.note: In [link]Jer. 31:33[/link], the source of this quotation, the word used is [i]law[/i] (singular), whereas in this verse it is [i]laws[/i] (plural). This proves that it is one law that spreads to become a number of laws. This one law is the law of life (see [i]the law of the Spirit of life[/i] — [link]Rom. 8:2[/link]). Every life has a law. The higher the life, the higher is its law. The divine life that we receive of God is the highest life; therefore, it has the highest law, the law referred to here. By imparting His divine life into us, God puts this highest law into our spirit, whence it spreads into our inward parts, such as our mind, emotion, and will, and becomes several laws.[br][br]The law of life differs from the law of letters. The law of life regulates us from within by and according to its life element, whereas the law of letters regulates us from without by and according to its dead letters. The law of dead letters depends on outward teachings, but the law of life depends on the inward consciousness. Since we all, great or small, have the law of life, we do not need outward teachings that are according to the law of letters ([link]v. 11[/link]).

Here, [i]mind[/i] corresponds with [i]inward parts[/i] in [link]Jer. 31:33[/link]. This proves that the mind is one of the inward parts and that it is the interpretation of the term [i]inward parts.[/i] The inward parts consist of not only the mind but also the emotion and the will. These three are components of the heart, mentioned in the succeeding clause.
First, God imparts His laws into us; then He inscribes them on us. He does the inscribing while we are experiencing the law of life.
Lit., I will be to them for God.

Lit., they will be to Me for a people. It is according to the law of life that we are a people to God and that He is God to us. God's relationship with us today is based fully on the law of life, so that today we do not need to walk according to the knowledge of the law of letters but should walk according to the consciousness of the law of life.

verse.text: And they shall by no means each [xref]a[/xref]teach his fellow citizen and each his brother, saying, [note]1[/note]Know the Lord; for all will [note]1[/note]know Me from the little one to the great one among them.
verse.note: In this verse two Greek words are used for [i]know:[/i] the first is [i]ginosko,[/i] which signifies the outward, objective knowledge; the second is [i]oida,[/i] which refers to the inward, subjective consciousness. In [link]John 8:55[/link] the Lord Jesus told the Pharisees that they did not know ([i]ginosko[/i]) God the Father (even in the outward, objective knowledge), and that He did know ([i]oida[/i]) the Father (in the inward, subjective consciousness). Both words are used in [link]1 John 2:29[/link].

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]I will be [note]1[/note]propitious to their unrighteousnesses, and their sins I shall by no means remember anymore."
verse.note: The word is the root of the Greek word for [i]make propitiation[/i] in [link]2:17[/link]. To be propitious is to make propitiation for our sins (see note [link]17[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]). In the new covenant four blessings are promised: (1) propitiation for our unrighteousnesses and the forgetting (forgiveness) of our sins ([link]v. 12[/link]); (2) the imparting of the law of life by the imparting of the divine life into us ([link]v. 10a[/link]); (3) the privilege of having God as our God and of being His people — the divine life's enabling us to participate in the enjoyment of God in fellowship with Him ([link]v. 10b[/link]); and (4) the function of life that enables us to know Him in the inward way of life ([link]v. 11[/link]). According to the covenant that God consummated, these four blessings are His promise. But according to the testament that the Lord bequeathed to us, they are His bequests. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

verse.text: In saying, A [xref]a[/xref]new [i]covenant,[/i] He has made the [note]1[/note]first old. But that which is becoming old and growing decrepit is near to [xref]b[/xref]disappearing.
verse.note: I.e., the old covenant. So also in [link]9:1[/link].

verse.text: Now then the [xref]a[/xref]first [i]covenant[/i] also had [xref]b[/xref]ordinances of service, and its [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]sanctuary was of [xref]d[/xref]this world.
verse.note: The same Greek word as for [i]holy places[/i] in [link]8:2[/link]. Here, however, it is singular and, hence, is rendered [i]sanctuary.[/i] The sanctuary is the entire tabernacle ([link]Exo. 25:8-9[/link]), including the first tabernacle, which is called the Holy Place ([link]v. 2[/link]), and the second tabernacle, which is called the Holy of Holies ([link]v. 3[/link]). See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].

verse.text: For a [xref]a[/xref]tabernacle was prepared, the first, in which were the [xref]b[/xref]lampstand and the [xref]c[/xref]table and the [xref]d[/xref]loaves that were set forth, which is called the [xref]e[/xref]Holy Place;
And after the second [xref]a[/xref]veil, a [xref]b[/xref]tabernacle, which is called the [xref]c[/xref]Holy of Holies,

[note]1[/note]Having a [xref]a[/xref]golden [note]2[/note]altar and the [xref]b[/xref]Ark of the Covenant covered about everywhere with gold, in which were the golden [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]pot that had the manna and Aaron's [xref]d[/xref]rod that budded and the [xref]e[/xref]tablets of the covenant,
verse.note: Regarding the place where the incense altar stood, there is apparently a discrepancy between the Old Testament and the New Testament. [link]Exodus 30:6[/link] says that the incense altar was put before the veil, i.e., outside the veil. This indicates clearly that the incense altar was put in the Holy Place, which is outside the veil, not in the Holy of Holies, which is within the veil. But here it says that the Holy of Holies has the incense altar. Therefore, most Christian teachers and Bible readers have thought that some error or misconstruction must somehow have occurred. But this is not so! The apparent discrepancy has great spiritual significance, as shown by the following points:[br][br](1) The Old Testament record of the incense altar's location implies the closest relationship between the incense altar and the Ark of the Testimony, over which was the expiation cover, where God met with His people ([link]Exo. 30:6[/link]). The record even says that the incense altar was set before the Ark of the Testimony, with no mention being made of the separating veil that stood between them ([link]Exo. 40:5[/link]).[br][br](2) [link]First Kings 6:22[/link] (ASV) says that the incense "altar...belonged to the oracle." The Hebrew word for [i]oracle[/i] includes the meaning [i]the speaking place of God.[/i] The oracle denotes the Holy of Holies, in which was the Ark of the Testimony with the expiation cover, where God spoke to His people. Thus, the Old Testament indicated beforehand that the incense altar belonged to the Holy of Holies. (Though the incense altar was in the Holy Place, its function was for the Ark of the Testimony in the Holy of Holies. On the Day of Expiation, both the incense altar and the expiation cover of the Ark of the Testimony were sprinkled with the same blood for expiation — [link]Exo. 30:10[/link]; [link]Lev. 16:15-16[/link].) Hence, in [link]Exo. 26:35[/link] only the showbread table and the lampstand are mentioned as being in the Holy Place; the incense altar is not mentioned.[br][br](3) The incense altar is related to prayer ([link]Luke 1:10-11[/link]), and in this book we are shown that to pray is to enter the Holy of Holies ([link]10:19[/link]) and to come to the throne of grace, which is signified by the expiation cover over the Ark of the Testimony in the Holy of Holies. Our prayer often begins with our mind, which is a part of our soul, signified by the Holy Place. But our prayer always ushers us into our spirit, signified by the Holy of Holies.[br][br](4) On account of all the above points, the writer of this book had to consider the incense altar as belonging to the Holy of Holies. [link]Verse 4[/link] does not say that a golden altar was in the Holy of Holies, as the lampstand and the table were in the Holy Place ([link]v. 2[/link]). It says that the Holy of Holies had a golden altar, because the altar belonged to the Holy of Holies. This concept fits the entire emphasis of the book of Hebrews, i.e., that we should press on from the soul (signified by the Holy Place) to the spirit (signified by the Holy of Holies).[br][br]The incense altar belongs to the oracle — the speaking place of God, i.e., the Holy of Holies. The incense altar typifies Christ in His resurrection as the sweet and fragrant incense, in which God extends to us His well-pleased acceptance. We pray with such a Christ in order to contact God that God may be pleased to speak to us. We speak to God in our prayer with Christ as the sweet incense, and God speaks to us in the sweet savor of this incense. This is the dialogue in the sweet fellowship between us and God through Christ as the sweet incense.

The Greek word here for [i]altar[/i] can be translated [i]censer.[/i] But here it refers to the incense altar, not the censer; according to the record of the Old Testament, there was no incense censer in the Holy Place or in the Holy of Holies.

The arrangement of the furniture of the tabernacle portrays our experience of Christ. In the outer court were the bronze altar and the bronze laver ([link]Exo. 40:29-32[/link]). This signifies that our experience of Christ begins, in an outward sense, with His redemption, which was accomplished on the cross, and the cleansing of the Holy Spirit, which is based on Christ's redemption. In the Holy Place were the showbread table and the lampstand, with the incense altar located close to the Holy of Holies, in front of the Ark of the Testimony. The showbread table signifies our experience of Christ as our life supply, and the lampstand, our experience of Christ as the shining light. These experiences are rather inward, in the intellect and consciousness of our being. The incense altar signifies our experience of Christ as the sweet incense ascending to God. This experience is deeper and more inward, leading to the deepest and most inward experiences, in the Holy of Holies. In the Holy of Holies was the Ark of the Testimony, in which were the golden pot containing the hidden manna; Aaron's budding rod; and the tablets of the covenant. The hidden manna in the golden pot signifies our experience of Christ as our life supply in the deepest way, an experience much deeper than that signified by the showbread table in the Holy Place. The budding rod signifies our experience of Christ in His resurrection as our acceptance by God for authority in the God-given ministry. This is deeper than the experience of Christ as the incense for our acceptance by God. The tablets of the covenant, which are the tablets of the Ten Commandments, signify our experience of Christ as the enlightening inner law, which regulates us according to God's divine nature. This is deeper than the experience of Christ as the shining lampstand in the Holy Place. All these deepest experiences of Christ take place in our spirit, signified by the Holy of Holies.

verse.text: And above it [xref]a[/xref]cherubim of glory overshadowing the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]expiation cover, concerning which it is not now [i]the time[/i] to speak in detail.
verse.note: Lit., propitiation place. See note [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 3[/link].

verse.text: Now these things having been thus prepared, [xref]a[/xref]into the [xref]b[/xref]first tabernacle the priests enter [xref]c[/xref]continually, accomplishing their worship;

But into the [xref]a[/xref]second, only the [xref]b[/xref]high priest [i]enters,[/i] [xref]c[/xref]once a year [i]and[/i] not without [xref]d[/xref]blood, which he offers for [xref]e[/xref]himself and for the [note]1[/note]sins of ignorance of the [xref]f[/xref]people,
verse.note: Lit., ignorances. The word refers to those sins that are committed in ignorance of God's law; hence, they are sins of ignorance ([link]Lev. 4:2[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]22[/link], [link]27[/link]; [link]5:17-18[/link]).

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]Holy Spirit [i]thus[/i] making this clear, that the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]way of the [xref]c[/xref][i]Holy of[/i] Holies has not yet been manifested while the [xref]d[/xref]first tabernacle still has [i]its[/i] standing,
verse.note: The first tabernacle, the Holy Place, signifies the old covenant, and the second tabernacle, the Holy of Holies, signifies the new covenant. The veil that closed off the Holy of Holies was rent ([link]Matt. 27:51[/link]) by the death of Christ, which crucified the flesh ([link]10:20[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:24[/link]), and now the way of the Holy of Holies has been manifested. Hence, we do not need to remain in the Holy Place, i.e., the old covenant, the soul; we must enter into the Holy of Holies, i.e., the new covenant, the spirit. That is the goal of this book.

verse.text: Which is a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]figure for the present time. According to [i]this tabernacle[/i] both [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]gifts and sacrifices are offered, which are [xref]c[/xref]unable to perfect, according to [xref]d[/xref]conscience, him who worships,
verse.note: Or, symbol, type; lit., parable.
See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: [i]Consisting[/i] only of [xref]a[/xref]foods and drinks and various [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]washings, being ordinances of the flesh, imposed until the time of [note]2[/note]setting things right.
verse.note: Lit., baptisms; as in [link]6:2[/link] (see note 1 there).

Or, reformation, putting in order, setting things straight. The time of setting things right occurred at Christ's first coming, when He fulfilled all the shadows of the Old Testament that a new covenant might replace the old. This is a right arrangement, a right ordering. Hence, it is a reformation. This is different from the restoration in [link]Acts 3:21[/link], which will occur at Christ's second coming.

verse.text: But Christ, having come as a [xref]a[/xref]High Priest of [note]1[/note]the [xref]b[/xref]good things that have come into being, through the greater and more perfect [xref]c[/xref]tabernacle not [xref]d[/xref]made by hands, that is, not of [xref]e[/xref]this creation,
verse.note: Some ancient MSS read, the good things to come.

verse.text: And not through the [xref]a[/xref]blood of goats and calves but through His [xref]b[/xref]own blood, [xref]c[/xref]entered [xref]d[/xref]once for all into the [xref]e[/xref][i]Holy of[/i] Holies, [note]1[/note]obtaining an [xref]f[/xref]eternal [note]2[/note]redemption.
verse.note: Christ accomplished redemption on the cross ([link]Col. 1:20[/link]), but it was not until He entered into the heavenly Holy of Holies through the redeeming blood, i.e., when He brought His redeeming blood to offer it before God, that He obtained the redemption that has an eternal effect.

In the old covenant the blood of goats and calves only made expiation for people's sins ([link]Lev. 16:15-18[/link]); it never accomplished redemption for their sins, because it is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins ([link]10:4[/link]). In Hebrew the root of the word for [i]expiation[/i] means [i]to cover.[/i] Thus, to make expiation means to cover sins; it does not mean to take away sins. Since Christ as the Lamb of God took away the sin of the world ([link]John 1:29[/link]) by offering Himself once for all on the cross as the sacrifice for sins ([link]v. 14[/link]; [link]10:12[/link]), His blood, which He sprinkled in the heavenly tabernacle ([link]12:24[/link]), has accomplished an eternal redemption for us, even the redemption of the transgressions under the first (old) covenant ([link]v. 15[/link]), transgressions that were only covered by animal blood. Thus, we have been redeemed with the precious blood of Christ ([link]1 Pet. 1:18-19[/link]). See note 1[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 16.

verse.text: For if the [xref]a[/xref]blood of goats and bulls and the [xref]b[/xref]ashes of a heifer [xref]c[/xref]sprinkling those who are [note]1[/note]defiled sanctify to the purity of the flesh,
verse.note: Lit., made common.

verse.text: How much more will the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blood of Christ, who through the [note]2[/note]eternal Spirit [xref]b[/xref]offered Himself [xref]c[/xref]without blemish to God, purify our [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]conscience from [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]dead works to [xref]f[/xref]serve the [note]5[/note][xref]g[/xref]living God?
verse.note: The blood of Christ was shed for the forgiveness of sins ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]), and the new covenant was consummated with it ([link]10:29[/link]; [link]Luke 22:20[/link]). It accomplished an eternal redemption for us ([link]v. 12[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:7[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:18-19[/link]) and purchased the church for God ([link]Acts 20:28[/link]). It washes us from our sins ([link]1 John 1:7[/link]), purifies our conscience ([link]v. 14[/link]), sanctifies us ([link]13:12[/link]), and speaks something better for us ([link]12:24[/link]). By this blood we enter the Holy of Holies ([link]10:19[/link]) and overcome Satan the accuser ([link]Rev. 12:10-11[/link]). Therefore, it is precious and better than the blood of goats and bulls ([link]vv. 12-13[/link]). We must value it highly and should not regard it a common thing, like animal blood. If we do, we will suffer God's punishment ([link]10:29-31[/link]).

On the cross Christ offered Himself to God in the human body ([link]10:5[/link], [link]10[/link]), which was under the limitation of time. But He offered Himself through the eternal Spirit, who is of eternity and is not under the limitation of time. Hence, in the eyes of God, Christ as the Lamb of God was slain from the foundation of the world ([link]Rev. 13:8[/link]). His offering of Himself was once for all ([link]7:27[/link]), and the redemption consummated through His death is eternal ([link]v. 12[/link]), having an eternal effect. The span of His redemption fully covers the span of sin. See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup][/link], par. 2.

The blood of Christ purifies our conscience to serve the living God. To serve the living God requires a blood-purified conscience. To worship in dead religion or to serve any dead thing, anything that is outside God, does not require our conscience to be purified. The conscience is the leading part of our spirit. The living God whom we desire to serve always comes to our spirit ([link]John 4:24[/link]) by touching our conscience. He is righteous, holy, and living. Our defiled conscience needs to be purified that we may serve Him in a living way. To worship God in our mind in a religious way does not require this.
Since we were dead ([link]Eph. 2:1[/link]; [link]Col. 2:13[/link]), whatever we did, whether bad or good, was dead works before the living God.

This book does not teach religion; rather, it reveals the living God ([link]3:12[/link]; [link]9:14[/link]; [link]10:31[/link]; [link]12:22[/link]). To touch this living God we need to exercise our spirit ([link]4:12[/link]) and have a blood-purified conscience in our spirit.

verse.text: And because of this He is the [xref]a[/xref]Mediator of a [xref]b[/xref]new covenant, so that, death having taken place for redemption of the [note]1[/note]transgressions under the [xref]c[/xref]first covenant, those who have been [xref]d[/xref]called might receive the [note]2[/note]promise of the [note]3[/note]eternal [xref]e[/xref]inheritance.
verse.note: I.e., transgressions reckoned as sins according to the standard of the provisions of the first covenant.

The promise of the eternal inheritance is based on Christ's eternal redemption, not on our work, and is different from the promise in [link]10:36[/link], which is conditioned on our endurance and our doing the will of God. (See note [link]36[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].) The eternal inheritance in the promise here is through the eternal redemption of Christ, whereas the great reward ([link]10:35[/link]) in the promise in [link]10:36[/link] is given by virtue of our endurance and our doing the will of God.
See note [link]34[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: For where there is a [note]1[/note]testament, the death of him who made the testament must of necessity be established.
verse.note: In Greek the same word is used for both [i]covenant[/i] and [i]testament.[/i] A covenant is an agreement containing some promises to accomplish certain things for the covenanted people, while a testament is a will containing certain accomplished things that are bequeathed to the inheritor. The new covenant consummated with the blood of Christ is not merely a covenant but a testament in which all the things that were accomplished by the death of Christ have been bequeathed to us. First, God gave the promise that He would make a new covenant ([link]Jer. 31:31-34[/link]). Then Christ shed His blood to enact the covenant ([link]Luke 22:20[/link]). Since accomplished facts are promised in this covenant, it is also a testament. This testament, this will, was confirmed and validated by Christ's death and is being executed and enforced by Christ in His resurrection. The promise of God's covenant is insured by God's faithfulness; God's covenant is guaranteed by God's righteousness; and the testament is enforced by Christ's resurrection power.

verse.text: For a [note]1[/note]testament is confirmed [note]2[/note]in the case of the dead, since it never has force when he who made the testament is living.
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Lit., over the dead.

verse.text: Hence neither was the [xref]a[/xref]first [i]covenant[/i] [note]1[/note]initiated without [xref]b[/xref]blood;
verse.note: The word implies the sense of [i]newly enacted, inaugurated.[/i]

verse.text: For when every commandment according to the law had been spoken by Moses to all the people, he [xref]a[/xref]took the blood of the calves and the goats, with water and [xref]b[/xref]scarlet wool and hyssop, and sprinkled both the scroll [i]of the covenant[/i] itself and all the people,
Saying, "This is the blood of the covenant which God has commanded to you."
And both the [xref]a[/xref]tabernacle and all the vessels of the service he sprinkled in like manner with the blood.
And almost all things are purified by blood according to the law, and [note]1[/note]without shedding of [xref]a[/xref]blood there is no forgiveness.
verse.note: Without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness of sins. Without forgiveness of sins there is no way for the requirement of God's righteousness to be fulfilled that the covenant may be enacted. But Christ's blood was shed for the forgiveness of sins, and the covenant was enacted with His blood ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]).

verse.text: It was necessary therefore for the [xref]a[/xref]examples of the things in the heavens to be purified by these, but the [note]1[/note]heavenly things themselves, by [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]better sacrifices than these.
verse.note: The tabernacle and all things pertaining to it were sprinkled with and purified by the blood of goats and bulls ([link]vv. 21-23[/link]). That was a figure showing that the heavenly things needed to be purified by the blood of better sacrifices, which are the sacrifices of Christ ([link]7:27[/link]; [link]9:14[/link], [link]28[/link]; [link]10:10[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]14[/link]). Heaven and all things in heaven were defiled by the rebellion of Satan and the fallen angels, who followed Satan in his rebellion against God. So all the heavenly things needed to be purified. Christ accomplished this purification with His own blood when He entered into heaven itself ([link]v. 24[/link]).

Christ offered Himself as the one sacrifice ([link]v. 14[/link]; [link]10:12[/link]). This one sacrifice, viewed from its various aspects, can be considered many sacrifices. As Christ is the eternal Son of the living God incarnated to be the Son of Man, and as He offered Himself to God through the eternal Spirit, so His sacrifices, which are Himself, are better than the animal sacrifices. Those were shadows that could never remove sins ([link]10:11[/link]), but His sacrifices are real and have put away sin once for all ([link]v. 26[/link]). Thus He obtained an eternal redemption for us ([link]v. 12[/link]).

verse.text: For Christ did not [xref]a[/xref]enter into a [note]1[/note]holy place made by hands, a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]figure of the [xref]c[/xref]true, but into [xref]d[/xref]heaven itself, to appear now before the face of God for us;
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].
Or, copy.

verse.text: Nor in order that He might offer Himself often, just as the [xref]a[/xref]high priest enters into the [xref]b[/xref][i]Holy of[/i] Holies year by year by the blood of other [i]creatures;[/i]

Since then He would have had to suffer often [xref]a[/xref]since the foundation of the world. But now [xref]b[/xref]once at the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]consummation of the ages He has been [xref]d[/xref]manifested for the [xref]e[/xref]putting away of sin through the [xref]f[/xref]sacrifice of Himself.
verse.note: Or, completion of the ages, end of the ages. Here it means the end of the Old Testament age, whereas [i]the consummation of the age[/i] in [link]Matt. 28:20[/link] refers to the close of the church age.[br][br]Christ was foreordained for us before the foundation of the world ([link]1 Pet. 1:20[/link]), and He was slain from the foundation of the world ([link]Rev. 13:8[/link]). Actually, His being slain occurred once for all at the consummation of the ages, when He offered Himself to God, in His first manifestation, for the putting away of sin. See note [link]14[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And inasmuch as it is [note]1[/note]reserved for men to [xref]a[/xref]die [note]2[/note]once, and after this [i]comes[/i] [xref]b[/xref]judgment,
verse.note: Or, laid up.

As man has to die once and be judged after dying, so Christ died once to bear man's sins ([link]v. 28[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]) and on the cross suffered judgment for man ([link]Isa. 53:5[/link], [link]11[/link]).

verse.text: So Christ also, having been offered [xref]a[/xref]once to [xref]b[/xref]bear the sins of many, will [xref]c[/xref]appear a second time to those who [xref]d[/xref]eagerly await Him, [note]1[/note]apart from sin, unto [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]salvation.
verse.note: Since in His first appearing Christ put away sin ([link]v. 26[/link]; [link]1 John 3:5[/link]), His second appearing will be apart from sin, having nothing to do with sin.

Salvation here means the redemption of our body and deliverance from the vanity and slavery of corruption of the old creation into the freedom of the glory of the children of God ([link]Rom. 8:18-23[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:20-21[/link]). This is to be glorified ([link]Rom. 8:17[/link], [link]30[/link]).

verse.text: For the law, having a [xref]a[/xref]shadow of the [xref]b[/xref]good things to come, not the image itself of the things, can [xref]c[/xref]never by the same sacrifices year by year, which they offer continually, [xref]d[/xref]perfect those who draw near.
Otherwise would they not have [xref]a[/xref]ceased to be offered, because those worshipping, having once been purified, would have no longer had the [xref]b[/xref]consciousness of sins?
But in those [i]sacrifices[/i] there is a bringing to mind of sins [xref]a[/xref]year by year;
For it is [xref]a[/xref]impossible for the [xref]b[/xref]blood of bulls and goats to [xref]c[/xref]take away sins.
Therefore, coming into the world, He says, [xref]a[/xref]"Sacrifice and offering You did not desire, but a [xref]b[/xref]body You have prepared for Me.
In [xref]a[/xref]burnt offerings and [xref]b[/xref][i]sacrifices[/i] for sin You did not delight.
Then I said, Behold, I have come [xref]a[/xref](in the [note]1[/note]roll of the book it is written concerning Me) to do Your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]will, O God."
verse.note: The Old Testament gives us a full record of Christ, either by plain words or by types ([link]Luke 24:27[/link], [link]44[/link], [link]46[/link]; [link]John 5:39[/link], [link]46[/link]).

The will of God here was to take away the first, the animal sacrifices of the old covenant, that the second, the sacrifice of Christ of the new testament, might be established. So in [link]vv. 9-10[/link].

verse.text: Saying above, "Sacrifices and offerings and burnt offerings and [i]sacrifices[/i] for sin You did not desire nor delight in" (which are offered according to the law),
He then has said, "Behold, I have come to do Your will." He takes away the [note]1[/note]first that He may establish the [note]1[/note]second,
verse.note: [i]The[/i] first here refers to the sacrifices of the first covenant, the old covenant; [i]the[/i] second refers to the sacrifice of the second covenant, the new covenant, which sacrifice is Christ. Christ came into the world that He might, according to the will of God, put away the animal sacrifices of the old covenant and establish Himself as the sacrifice of the new covenant.

verse.text: By which [xref]a[/xref]will we have been [xref]b[/xref]sanctified through the [xref]c[/xref]offering of the [xref]d[/xref]body of Jesus Christ [note]1[/note][xref]e[/xref]once for all.
verse.note: The main thought in [link]vv. 1-18[/link] is that Christ has removed sins, accomplishing what all the Levitical sacrifices were unable to do. Having put away sin once for all, Christ has now imparted Himself into us as the divine life so that through the working of this divine life we may become the corporate reproduction of Himself.

verse.text: And every priest [note]1[/note]stands daily, ministering and offering often the same sacrifices, which can [xref]a[/xref]never [xref]b[/xref]remove sins;
verse.note: The priests in the old covenant stood daily and offered the same sacrifices again and again, because what they offered could never remove sins. But Christ put away sin ([link]9:26[/link]) by offering Himself to God as the one sacrifice for sins, whereupon He sat down forever on the right hand of God ([link]v. 12[/link]). His sitting in heaven is a sign and proof that the removing of sins has been accomplished. His sitting there is forever. Hence, He no longer needs to do anything for sin. He did it once for all. His sitting down forever after having offered one sacrifice for sins is in contrast to the priests' standing daily to offer often the same sacrifices.

verse.text: But this One, having [xref]a[/xref]offered one [xref]b[/xref]sacrifice for sins, [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]sat down [note]2[/note]forever on the right hand of God,
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Lit., unto perpetuity. So in [link]v. 14[/link].

verse.text: Henceforth waiting until His [xref]a[/xref]enemies are made the footstool for His feet.
For by [xref]a[/xref]one offering He has [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]perfected forever those who are being [xref]c[/xref]sanctified.
verse.note: Or, completed. Christ has already perfected and completed us through His one offering.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]Holy Spirit also testifies to us, for after having said,
[xref]a[/xref]"This is the covenant which I will covenant with them after those days, says the Lord: I will impart My laws upon their hearts, and upon their mind I will inscribe them,"
[i]He then says,[/i] "And [xref]a[/xref]their sins and their lawlessnesses I shall by no means remember anymore."
Now where forgiveness of these is, there is [xref]a[/xref]no longer an offering for sin.
Having therefore, brothers, [xref]a[/xref]boldness for [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]entering the [xref]c[/xref][i]Holy of[/i] Holies in the [xref]d[/xref]blood of Jesus,
verse.note: The Holy of Holies today is in heaven, where the Lord Jesus is ([link]9:12[/link], [link]24[/link]). How, then, can we enter the Holy of Holies while we are still on earth? The secret is our spirit, referred to in [link]4:12[/link]. The very Christ who is in heaven is now also in our spirit ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]). As the heavenly ladder ([link]Gen. 28:12[/link]; [link]John 1:51[/link]), He joins our spirit to heaven and brings heaven into our spirit. Hence, whenever we turn to our spirit, we enter into the Holy of Holies. There we meet with God, who is on the throne of grace. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: Which [i]entrance[/i] He initiated for us as a [note]1[/note]new and living [xref]a[/xref]way through the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]veil, that is, His [xref]c[/xref]flesh,
verse.note: Lit., recently opened.

This is the second veil ([link]Heb. 9:3[/link]) within the tabernacle, which veil typifies the flesh of Christ. When Christ's flesh was crucified, this veil was rent ([link]Matt. 27:51[/link]), thus opening the way for us, those who were alienated from God, who is signified by the tree of life ([link]Gen. 3:22-24[/link]), to enter into the Holy of Holies to contact Him and take Him as the tree of life for our enjoyment. This implies that because our old man was crucified with Christ, we have an open way to contact and enjoy God in our spirit as our life and life supply.

verse.text: And [i]having[/i] a [xref]a[/xref]great [xref]b[/xref]Priest over the [xref]c[/xref]house of God,

Let us [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]come forward to [i]the[/i] [xref]b[/xref][i]Holy of Holies[/i] with a true heart in full [xref]c[/xref]assurance of faith, having our hearts [xref]d[/xref]sprinkled from an evil conscience and having our [note]2[/note]bodies [xref]e[/xref]washed with [note]2[/note]pure water.
verse.note: [i]Come forward[/i] (to the Holy of Holies) is in contrast to [i]shrink back[/i] (to Judaism) in [link]vv. 38-39[/link].

Both the bodies and the pure water here are figurative, like the spot, the wrinkle, and the water in [link]Eph. 5:26-27[/link]. The body refers to our visible outward being, just as the heart refers to our invisible inward being. The pure water refers to the Lord's living word that cleanses our outward conduct and walk (cf. [link]John 15:3[/link]).

verse.text: Let us [xref]a[/xref]hold fast the [xref]b[/xref]confession of our [xref]c[/xref]hope unwavering, for He who has promised is [xref]d[/xref]faithful;
And let us consider one another so as to incite [i]one another[/i] to love and good works,

Not [note]1[/note]abandoning our own [note]2[/note]assembling together, as the custom with some is, but [xref]a[/xref]exhorting [i]one another;[/i] and so much the more as you see the [xref]b[/xref]day drawing [xref]c[/xref]near.
verse.note: For the Hebrew believers, at their time and in their situation, to abandon their own assembling together would have been to abandon the new covenant way of contacting God, to abandon the church and return to their old religion — Judaism. This would have broken God's administration of grace, thus constituting a serious sin before God ([link]v. 26[/link]).

Our assembling together as Christians. In those days the Hebrews who believed in the Lord had come out of Judaism and had formerly gone to the gatherings in Judaism. When they believed in Christ and became Christians, they attended Christian gatherings; this equaled their being separated from Judaism. Therefore, if any of them had gone back to the gatherings in Judaism, that would have been equivalent to their being separated from the proper Christian assemblings, which are according to God's New Testament economy. Hence, Paul exhorted them not to abandon their own assembling together as Christians.

verse.text: For when we [note]1[/note]sin willfully after receiving the knowledge of the [note]2[/note]truth, there [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]no longer remains a [xref]b[/xref]sacrifice [i]of bulls and goats[/i] for sins,
verse.note: To sin willfully here means to abandon one's own assembling together with the church. The Hebrew believers had been instructed to abandon Judaism and remain under the new covenant. If they had still returned to Judaism, they would have abandoned their own assembling with the church. This would have constituted a willful sin in the eyes of God, in that it would have been committed after they had received the knowledge of the truth, after they had come to know that God had abandoned Judaism, which was formed according to the old covenant, and had initiated the new and living way of contacting God according to the new covenant.

[i]Truth[/i] here refers to the things disclosed in the foregoing chapters and verses; those things afforded the Hebrew believers the full knowledge that God had annulled the old covenant and had established the new.

If the Hebrew believers had abandoned the church and returned to Judaism, there would have remained no sacrifice for sins in the economy of God, for all the sacrifices of the old covenant had been altogether replaced by the one sacrifice of Christ. Since Christ offered Himself once for all as the sacrifice for our sins ([link]7:27[/link]; [link]10:10[/link], [link]12[/link]), the sacrifice for sins ceased ([link]v. 2[/link]). It was taken away by Christ ([link]v. 9[/link]), who offered Himself to God as the real sacrifice for our sins.

verse.text: But a certain [xref]a[/xref]fearful expectation of [xref]b[/xref]judgment and [xref]c[/xref]fervor of fire, which is to [xref]d[/xref]consume the adversaries.
[xref]a[/xref]Anyone who has set aside the law of Moses dies without compassion on [i]the testimony of[/i] [xref]b[/xref]two or three witnesses.

[xref]a[/xref]By [xref]b[/xref]how much do you think he will be thought worthy of [note]1[/note]worse punishment who has [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]trampled underfoot the Son of God and has [note]3[/note]considered [xref]d[/xref]the blood of the covenant by which he was [xref]e[/xref]sanctified a common thing and has [note]4[/note]insulted the [xref]f[/xref]Spirit of grace?
verse.note: This is different from suffering the second death, which is to perish in the lake of fire for eternity ([link]Rev. 20:6[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]21:8[/link]). Although believers cannot be lost, they may suffer some dispensational punishment for their failures. This punishment will be worse than that received by those who broke the law of letters.

In the new covenant the Son of God replaces all the sacrifices of the old covenant. If the Hebrew believers had returned to Judaism to offer any of the old sacrifices, they would have been, in effect, trampling underfoot the Son of God.

If the Hebrew believers had returned to Judaism to offer the old sacrifices and thus rely on the blood of slain animals, they would have been, in effect, considering the precious blood of Christ a common thing. This would have been to seriously disregard the unique redemptive work of Christ.

Under the new covenant, through the redeeming blood of Christ, the Hebrew believers became partakers of the Holy Spirit ([link]6:4[/link]), the Spirit of grace. If they had returned to Judaism, the Spirit of grace, who dwelled in them and worked in them, would have been insulted by their willful sin.

verse.text: For we know Him who said, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]"Vengeance is Mine; I will repay"; and again, [xref]b[/xref]"The Lord will [xref]c[/xref]judge His people."
verse.note: The Greek word conveys no thought of vindictiveness; rather, it implies a full meting out of justice to all parties.

verse.text: It is a [xref]a[/xref]fearful thing to fall into the hands of the [xref]b[/xref]living God.
But call to mind the former days, in which, having been [xref]a[/xref]enlightened, you endured a great [xref]b[/xref]conflict of [xref]c[/xref]sufferings;

On one hand, being made a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spectacle both in [xref]b[/xref]reproaches and in afflictions, and on the other, having become [xref]c[/xref]partakers with those who are treated the same.
verse.note: A show exposed to the public, a gazingstock. The same thing happened to the apostles ([link]1 Cor. 4:9[/link]).

verse.text: For you both sympathized with those in [xref]a[/xref]bonds and accepted with [xref]b[/xref]joy the plundering of your possessions, knowing that you yourselves have a [note]1[/note]better [xref]c[/xref]possession and one that abides.
verse.note: This better and abiding possession is the eternal inheritance ([link]9:15[/link]) and the incorruptible, undefiled, and unfading inheritance that is kept in the heavens ([link]1 Pet. 1:4[/link]). Under the old covenant the Jewish people inherited earthly things as their possession; but under the new covenant the believers inherit the heavenly riches as their possession. This better and abiding possession was a great incentive to the Hebrew believers to suffer the loss of earthly things.

verse.text: Do not cast away therefore your [xref]a[/xref]boldness, which has great [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]reward.
verse.note: The reward is something in addition to eternal salvation. Eternal salvation is obtained through faith, having nothing to do with our works ([link]Eph. 2:8-9[/link]), whereas the reward is given for the work that we do after we are saved ([link]1 Cor. 3:8[/link], [link]14[/link]). We may not receive a reward but may suffer loss, even though we are saved, because we are void of the work that the Lord approves ([link]1 Cor. 3:15[/link]). The reward will be given to us at the Lord's coming back, according to our works ([link]Matt. 16:27[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:12[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 4:5[/link]). What we receive will be decided at the judgment seat of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]) and will be enjoyed in the coming kingdom ([link]Matt. 25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]). The apostle Paul strived to gain the reward ([link]1 Cor. 9:24-27[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:13-14[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:7-8[/link]). Even Moses looked away to the reward ([link]11:26[/link]; see note 3 there). Here the Hebrew believers were charged not to miss the reward — the coming Sabbath rest ([link]4:9[/link]), the enjoyment of Christ and the reigning with Christ in the coming kingdom.

verse.text: For you have need of [xref]a[/xref]endurance in order that, having done the [note]1[/note]will of God, you may obtain the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]promise.
verse.note: The will of God here for the Hebrew believers was that they take the new covenant way ([link]vv. 19-23[/link]) and remain with the church ([link]v. 25[/link]), not shrinking back to Judaism ([link]vv. 38-39[/link]) but suffering persecution from Judaism ([link]vv. 32-34[/link]). For this they would receive the promise of a great reward ([link]v. 35[/link]) at the Lord's coming back ([link]v. 37[/link]).

The promise here is the promise of the Sabbath rest mentioned in [link]4:9[/link], a rest in which we will reign with Christ in the coming kingdom. That will be the great reward mentioned in [link]v. 35[/link], which is the gaining of the soul mentioned in [link]v. 39[/link]. This promise is conditioned on our endurance and our doing the will of God. It differs from the promise in [link]9:15[/link]. See note 2 there.

verse.text: "For in yet a very little while the Coming One will [xref]a[/xref]come and will not delay.
But My [xref]a[/xref]righteous one shall live [xref]b[/xref]by [note]1[/note]faith; and if he shrinks back, My soul does not delight in him."
verse.note: After this verse and the next, [link]ch. 11[/link] gives a full definition of faith.

verse.text: But we are not of those who [note]1[/note]shrink back to [note]2[/note]ruin but of them who have faith to the [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]gaining of the soul.
verse.note: For the Hebrew believers to shrink back to Judaism was for them to shrink back to ruin, which is not eternal perdition but punishment meted out by the living God ([link]vv. 29-31[/link]). See next note.

The ruin here is the punishment mentioned in [link]vv. 27-31[/link], which will come upon those who forsake the new covenant and return to Judaism, thus trampling underfoot the Son of God, regarding Christ's precious blood a common thing, like animal blood, and insulting the Spirit of grace.

Or, saving, preserving, possessing. Our being is of three parts — spirit, soul, and body ([link]1 Thes. 5:23[/link]), and our soul is different from our spirit. At the time that we believed in the Lord Jesus and were saved, our spirit was regenerated with the Spirit of God ([link]John 3:6[/link]). But we must wait until the Lord Jesus comes back for our body to be redeemed, saved, and transfigured ([link]Rom. 8:23-25[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:21[/link]). Concerning the saving, or gaining, of our soul, it depends on how we deal with our soul in following the Lord after we are saved and regenerated. If we lose our soul now for the Lord's sake, we will save it ([link]Matt. 16:25[/link]; [link]Luke 9:24[/link]; [link]17:33[/link]; [link]John 12:25[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:9[/link]), and it will be saved, or gained, at the Lord's coming back ([link]v. 37[/link]). This gaining of the soul will be the reward ([link]v. 35[/link]) of the kingdom to the overcoming followers of the Lord ([link]Matt. 16:22-28[/link]).

verse.text: Now [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]faith is the [note]2[/note]substantiation of things [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]hoped for, the [note]4[/note]conviction of things [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]not seen.
verse.note: After presenting in the first ten chapters a thorough comparison of Judaism and God's economy, this book charges the Hebrew believers, who were in danger of shrinking back, to live, to walk, to go on, by faith ([link]10:38-39[/link]), that is, not by appearance ([link]2 Cor. 5:7[/link]). Then, in [link]ch. 11[/link] it goes on to define faith according to the history of faith. Both the eternal inheritance ([link]9:15[/link]) and the great reward ([link]10:35[/link]) promised by God are things hoped for and things not seen. Faith is the substantiation of things hoped for. Hence, it is the assurance, the confidence, the confirmation, the reality, the essence, the supporting ground, of things hoped for, the foundation that supports the things hoped for. Faith is also the conviction of things not seen. It convinces us of what we do not see. Hence, it is the evidence, the proof, of things not seen.

The same Greek word is used for [i]substance[/i] in [link]1:3[/link], [i]assurance[/i] in [link]3:14[/link], and [i]confidence[/i] (in which one knows that he has a sure foundation) in [link]2 Cor. 11:17[/link]. Moreover, it can be translated [i]confirmation, reality, essence[/i] (which denotes the real nature of things, as opposed to the appearance), [i]foundation,[/i] or [i]supporting ground.[/i] The word means, primarily, [i]substance,[/i] but here it denotes the substantiating of the substance (of the things hoped for); hence, it is translated [i]substantiation.[/i] The word [i]substantiate[/i] is [i]substance[/i] in verb form; to substantiate is to give substance to the reality of the substance not seen. This is the action of faith. Therefore, it says here that faith is the substantiation of things hoped for.

The unbelievers, being without Christ, have no hope ([link]Eph. 2:12[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:13[/link]). But we, the believers in Christ, are a people of hope. The calling that we receive from God brings us hope ([link]Eph. 1:18[/link]; [link]4:4[/link]). We have been regenerated unto a living hope ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]). Our Christ, who is in us, is the hope of glory ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:1[/link]), which will issue in the redemption, the transfiguration, of our body in glory ([link]Rom. 8:23-25[/link]). This is the hope of salvation ([link]1 Thes. 5:8[/link]), a blessed hope ([link]Titus 2:13[/link]), a good hope ([link]2 Thes. 2:16[/link]), the hope of eternal life ([link]Titus 1:2[/link]; [link]3:7[/link]); it is also the hope of the glory of God ([link]Rom. 5:2[/link]), the hope of the gospel ([link]Col. 1:23[/link]), the hope laid up for us in the heavens ([link]Col. 1:5[/link]). We should keep this hope always ([link]1 John 3:3[/link]) and boast in it ([link]Rom. 5:2[/link]). Our God is the God of hope ([link]Rom. 15:13[/link]), and through the encouragement of the Scriptures we can have hope ([link]Rom. 15:4[/link]) all the time in God ([link]1 Pet. 1:21[/link]) and can rejoice in it ([link]Rom. 12:12[/link]). This book charges us to hold fast the boast of hope firm to the end ([link]3:6[/link]), to show diligence unto the full assurance of our hope until the end ([link]6:11[/link]), and to lay hold of the hope set before us ([link]6:18[/link]). It also tells us that the new covenant brings in a better hope, through which we draw near to God ([link]7:19[/link]). Our life should be a life of hope, which accompanies and abides with faith ([link]1 Pet. 1:21[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 13:13[/link]). We should follow Abraham, who beyond hope believed in hope ([link]Rom. 4:18[/link]).
The conviction of truth. The Greek word can be translated [i]evidence,[/i] or [i]proof.[/i]

All things hoped for are things not seen ([link]Rom. 8:24-25[/link]). As people of hope, we should aim our life not at the things that are seen but at the things that are not seen; for the things that are seen are temporary, but the things that are not seen are eternal ([link]2 Cor. 4:18[/link]). Hence, we walk by faith, not by appearance ([link]2 Cor. 5:7[/link]).

verse.text: For in this the elders have obtained a good [xref]a[/xref]testimony.

[note]1[/note]By faith we understand that the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]universe has been framed by the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]word of God, so that what is seen has not come into [xref]c[/xref]being out of things which appear.
verse.note: From [link]v. 3[/link] this chapter presents to us a brief history of faith — from God's creation, through all the generations of God's chosen people, to the New Testament believers ([link]v. 40[/link]) — to prove that faith is the unique pathway by which God's seekers receive His promise and take His way.
Lit., ages. See note [link]2[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
The Greek word denotes the instant word.

verse.text: By faith [xref]a[/xref]Abel offered to God a [note]1[/note]more excellent sacrifice than [xref]b[/xref]Cain, through which he obtained the [xref]c[/xref]testimony that he was righteous, God [xref]d[/xref]testifying to his gifts; and through [note]2[/note]faith, though he has died, he still [xref]e[/xref]speaks.
verse.note: This more excellent sacrifice was a type of Christ, who is the real "better sacrifices" ([link]9:23[/link]).
Lit., it.

verse.text: By faith [xref]a[/xref]Enoch was translated so that he should not see death; and he was not found, because God had translated him. For before his translation he obtained the [xref]b[/xref]testimony that he had been well pleasing to God.

But without faith it is impossible to [note]1[/note]be well pleasing [i]to Him,[/i] for he who [xref]a[/xref]comes forward to God must believe that He is and that He is a rewarder of those who [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]diligently seek Him.
verse.note: Or, please [i]Him.[/i]
Lit., seek Him out.

verse.text: By faith [xref]a[/xref]Noah, having been divinely instructed concerning things not yet seen [i]and[/i] being moved by pious fear, [xref]b[/xref]prepared an ark for the salvation of his house, through which he condemned the world, and became [xref]c[/xref]heir of the righteousness which is according to faith.

By faith [xref]a[/xref]Abraham, being called, obeyed to [xref]b[/xref]go out unto a place which he was to [xref]c[/xref]receive as an inheritance; and he went out, [note]1[/note]not knowing where he was going.
verse.note: This afforded Abraham constant opportunity to exercise his faith to trust in God for His instant leading, taking God's presence as the map for his traveling.

verse.text: By faith he dwelt as a foreigner in the [xref]a[/xref]land of promise as in a foreign [i]land,[/i] making his home in [xref]b[/xref]tents with Isaac and Jacob, the fellow [xref]c[/xref]heirs of the same promise;
For he eagerly waited for the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]city which has the [xref]b[/xref]foundations, whose Architect and Builder is [xref]c[/xref]God.
verse.note: This is the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem ([link]12:22[/link]), the Jerusalem above ([link]Gal. 4:26[/link]), the holy city, New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 21:2[/link]; [link]3:12[/link]), which God has prepared for His people ([link]v. 16[/link]), and the tabernacle of God, in which God will dwell with men for eternity ([link]Rev. 21:3[/link]). As the patriarchs waited for this city, so we also seek it ([link]13:14[/link]).

verse.text: By faith also [xref]a[/xref]Sarah herself received power to conceive seed, even beyond the season of age, since she considered Him [xref]b[/xref]faithful who promised.

Therefore also there were born of one, and that of him who had become [xref]a[/xref]dead, [i]as many[/i] as even the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]stars of heaven in multitude and as the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]sand by the [note]2[/note]seashore innumerable.
verse.note: The stars of heaven signify Abraham's heavenly descendants, the descendants who are of faith ([link]Gal. 3:7[/link], [link]29[/link]), whereas the sand by the seashore signifies Abraham's earthly descendants, the descendants in the flesh.
Lit., the lip of the sea.

verse.text: All [xref]a[/xref]these died [note]1[/note]in faith, [xref]b[/xref]not receiving the promises but [xref]c[/xref]seeing them from afar and joyfully greeting [i]them[/i] and confessing that they were [xref]d[/xref]strangers and [note]2[/note]sojourners on the earth.
verse.note: Lit., according to.

Or, pilgrims, exiles, expatriates. Abraham was the first Hebrew ([link]Gen. 14:13[/link]), a river crosser. He left Chaldea, the idolatrous land of curse, crossed the flood, the river Perath, or Euphrates ([link]Josh. 24:2-3[/link]), and came to Canaan, the good land of blessing. Yet he did not settle there; rather, he sojourned in the land of promise as a pilgrim, even as an exile, an expatriate, longing after a better country, a heavenly one ([link]v. 16[/link]), seeking a country of his own ([link]v. 14[/link]). This might imply that he was ready to cross another river, from the earthly side to the heavenly side. Isaac and Jacob followed him in the same steps, living on the earth as strangers and sojourners and waiting for the God-built city that has the foundations ([link]v. 10[/link]). The word in [link]vv. 9-16[/link] may imply that the writer of this book intended to impress on the memory of the believing Hebrews the fact that they, as the real Hebrews, should follow their forefathers, considering themselves strangers and sojourners on the earth and looking forward to the heavenly country, which is better than the earthly one.

verse.text: For those who say such things make it manifest that they seek after a [xref]a[/xref]country of their own.
And if indeed they continued to remember that [i]country[/i] from which they went out, they would have had opportunity to return;

But as it is, they long after a better [xref]a[/xref][i]country,[/i] that is, a [xref]b[/xref]heavenly one. Therefore God is [xref]c[/xref]not ashamed of them, to be called [xref]d[/xref]their God, for He has prepared a [xref]e[/xref]city for them.
By faith Abraham, being tested, [xref]a[/xref]offered up Isaac; indeed he who gladly received the [xref]b[/xref]promises was offering up his only begotten,
Of whom it was said, [xref]a[/xref]"In Isaac shall your seed be called";
Counting that God was [xref]a[/xref]able to [xref]b[/xref]raise [i]men[/i] even from the dead, from which he also received him back in [note]1[/note]figure.
verse.note: Lit., a parable.

verse.text: By faith [xref]a[/xref]Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau, even concerning things to come.
By faith [xref]a[/xref]Jacob, while he was dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph and [xref]b[/xref]worshipped [i]God, while[/i] [note]1[/note][i]leaning[/i] on the top of his staff.
verse.note: This signifies that Jacob confessed that he was a sojourner, a traveler, on the earth ([link]v. 13[/link]), and that God had shepherded him all his life long ([link]Gen. 48:15[/link]).

verse.text: By faith [xref]a[/xref]Joseph, nearing his end, made mention of the exodus of the sons of Israel and [xref]b[/xref]gave orders concerning his bones.

By faith [xref]a[/xref]Moses, when he was born, was hidden for three months by his parents because they saw that the child was [xref]b[/xref]lovely, and they did not fear the [xref]c[/xref]king's decree.
By faith Moses, when he had [xref]a[/xref]grown up, refused to be called the [xref]b[/xref]son of Pharaoh's daughter,
Choosing rather to be [xref]a[/xref]ill-treated with the people of God than to have the [note]1[/note]temporary [note]2[/note]enjoyment of sin,
verse.note: Or, for a while, fleeting, passing.
The enjoyment in Egypt, i.e., the enjoyment in the world, is sinful in the eyes of God. It is the enjoyment of sin, of a sinful life, and is temporary, fleeting, and passing.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Considering the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]reproach of the Christ greater riches than the [xref]c[/xref]treasures of Egypt; for he [xref]d[/xref]looked away to the [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]reward.
verse.note: Or, accounting, esteeming.

Christ, as the Angel of the Lord, was always with the children of Israel in their afflictions ([link]Exo. 3:2[/link], [link]7-9[/link]; [link]14:19[/link]; [link]Num. 20:16[/link]; [link]Isa. 63:9[/link]). Furthermore, the Scripture identifies Him with them ([link]Hosea 11:1[/link]; [link]Matt. 2:15[/link]). Hence, the reproach falling on them was considered His reproach, and the reproaches of those who reproached God fell also on Him ([link]Rom. 15:3[/link]). The New Testament believers, as His followers, bear His reproach ([link]13:13[/link]) and are reproached for His name ([link]1 Pet. 4:14[/link]). Moses, choosing to be ill-treated with the people of God ([link]v. 25[/link]), considered this kind of reproach, the reproach of the Christ of God, greater riches than the treasures of Egypt in Pharaoh's palace; for Moses looked away to the reward.

Because he was willing to suffer the reproach of the Christ, Moses will receive the reward of the kingdom. He was not allowed to enter into the rest of the good land because of his failure at Meribah ([link]Num. 20:12-13[/link]; [link]Deut. 4:21-22[/link]; [link]32:50-52[/link]), but he will be with Christ in the kingdom ([link]Matt. 16:28-17:3[/link]). In referring to this, surely the writer intended to encourage his readers who were suffering persecution for Christ's sake to follow Moses by considering the reproach of the Christ greater riches than the things they had lost, and by looking away to the reward. See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].

verse.text: By faith he [xref]a[/xref]left Egypt, not fearing the [xref]b[/xref]wrath of the king, for he [note]1[/note]persevered as one [xref]c[/xref]seeing the [xref]d[/xref]unseen One.
verse.note: Or, was steadfast.

verse.text: By faith he instituted the [xref]a[/xref]Passover and the pouring out of the blood so that the [xref]b[/xref]one destroying the firstborn would not touch them.
By faith they [xref]a[/xref]passed through the Red Sea as through dry land, in which the Egyptians, while making the attempt, were swallowed up.
[note]1[/note]By faith the [xref]a[/xref]walls of Jericho fell, having been [xref]b[/xref]encircled for a period of seven days.
verse.note: Nothing is mentioned here regarding the forty years during which the children of Israel wandered in the wilderness, since they did nothing by faith there to please God, but rather provoked God by their unbelief during those years ([link]3:16-18[/link]). Even their crossing of the Jordan River is not mentioned here, because that crossing was due to the delay caused by their unbelief. That crossing would not have been needed if they had not had the unbelief that disqualified them from entering the good land at Kadesh-barnea ([link]Deut. 1:19-46[/link]) just a short time after they left Mount Sinai ([link]Deut. 1:2[/link]).

verse.text: By faith [xref]a[/xref]Rahab the harlot did not perish with those who were disobedient, since she had [xref]b[/xref]received the spies with peace.

And what more shall I say? For time will fail me if I tell of [xref]a[/xref]Gideon, [xref]b[/xref]Barak, [xref]c[/xref]Samson, [xref]d[/xref]Jephthah, of [xref]e[/xref]David and [xref]f[/xref]Samuel and the prophets,
Who through faith [xref]a[/xref]overcame kingdoms, [xref]b[/xref]worked righteousness, [xref]c[/xref]obtained promises, [xref]d[/xref]stopped the mouths of lions,
[xref]a[/xref]Quenched the power of fire, [xref]b[/xref]escaped the edge of the sword, were made strong in weakness, became [xref]c[/xref]mighty in war, routed the armies of foreigners.

Women [xref]a[/xref]received their dead by resurrection; and others were tortured [i]to death,[/i] not accepting [note]1[/note]deliverance, in order that they might obtain a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]better resurrection.
verse.note: Or, release. The Greek word means [i]redemption[/i] (offered at a price).

The better resurrection is not only the first resurrection ([link]Rev. 20:4-6[/link]), the resurrection of life ([link]John 5:28-29[/link]), but also the out-resurrection ([link]Phil. 3:11[/link]), the extra-resurrection, the resurrection in which the Lord's overcomers will receive the reward ([link]v. 26[/link]) of the kingdom. This is what the apostle Paul sought after.

verse.text: And still others underwent the trial of [xref]a[/xref]mockings and scourgings, even, moreover, of bonds and [xref]b[/xref]imprisonment.

They were [xref]a[/xref]stoned, they were sawn in two, they were tempted, they died by the [xref]b[/xref]murder of the sword, they wandered about in sheepskins, in goatskins, destitute, afflicted, [xref]c[/xref]ill-treated
(Of [note]1[/note]whom the world was not worthy), wandering over [xref]a[/xref]deserts and [xref]b[/xref]mountains and [i]in[/i] [xref]c[/xref]caves and holes of the earth.
verse.note: These faith-people are an extra-people, a people on the highest plane, of whom the corrupted world is not worthy. Only the holy city of God, New Jerusalem, is worthy to have them.

verse.text: And these all, having obtained a good [xref]a[/xref]testimony through their faith, did [xref]b[/xref]not obtain the promise,
Because God has [note]1[/note]provided something [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]better for us, so that [note]3[/note]apart from us they would not be made perfect.
verse.note: Or, foreseen.

The Greek word means [i]superior,[/i] nobler, greater; hence, better. It is used thirteen times in this book: the better Christ ([link]1:4[/link]), better things ([link]6:9[/link]), a better hope ([link]7:19[/link]), a better covenant (twice — [link]7:22[/link]; [link]8:6[/link]), better promises ([link]8:6[/link]), better sacrifices ([link]9:23[/link]), a better possession ([link]10:34[/link]), a better country ([link]11:16[/link]), a better resurrection ([link]11:35[/link]), something better ([link]11:40[/link]), and better speaking ([link]12:24[/link]). (The other instance is in [link]7:7[/link], where it is translated [i]greater[/i].) All these better things are the fulfillment and reality of the things that the Old Testament saints had in types, figures, and shadows. What God provided at that time was a picture of the things concerning us, the things that were to come in the new covenant and that are the true and real things, better, stronger, more powerful, nobler, and greater than their types, figures, and shadows. The Old Testament saints, who had only the shadows, need us for their perfection that they may share with us in the real things of the new covenant. Why, then, should we leave the real things of the new covenant and turn to the shadows of the old covenant?

Both the participation in the kingdom for one thousand years ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]) and the sharing in the New Jerusalem for eternity ([link]Rev. 21:2-3[/link]; [link]22:1-5[/link]) are corporate matters. The kingdom feast will be for the overcomers of both the Old and New Testaments ([link]Matt. 8:11[/link]). The blessed New Jerusalem will be composed of both the Old Testament saints and the New Testament believers ([link]Rev. 21:12-14[/link]). Hence, apart from the New Testament believers, the Old Testament believers cannot obtain what God promised. To obtain and enjoy the good things of God's promise, they need the New Testament believers to perfect them. Now they are waiting for us to go on that they may be made perfect.

verse.text: Therefore let us also, having so great a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cloud of [note]2[/note]witnesses surrounding us, put away every [note]3[/note]encumbrance and the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]sin which so easily entangles [i]us[/i] and [xref]c[/xref]run with [xref]d[/xref]endurance the [note]5[/note]race which is set before us,
