verse.note: The cloud is for leading people to follow the Lord ([link]Num. 9:15-22[/link]), and the Lord is in the cloud to be with the people ([link]Exo. 13:21-22[/link]).
In Greek [i]witnesses[/i] implies the sense of martyrs.
Or, weight, burden, impediment. The runners of the race strip off every unnecessary weight, every encumbering burden, that nothing may impede them from winning the race.

Sin here refers mainly to the thing that entangles us and prevents us from running the race, just as the willful sin mentioned in [link]10:26[/link] would have kept the Hebrew believers away from the new covenant way in God's economy. (See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].) Both the encumbering weight and the entangling sin would have frustrated the Hebrew believers and restrained them from running the heavenly race in the new covenant way of following Jesus, who was rejected by Judaism.

The Christian life is a race. All the saved Christians must run the race to win the prize ([link]1 Cor. 9:24[/link]), not salvation in the common sense ([link]Eph. 2:8[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:15[/link]) but a reward in a special sense ([link]10:35[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:14[/link]). The apostle Paul ran the race and won the prize ([link]1 Cor. 9:26-27[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:13-14[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:7-8[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Looking away [xref]a[/xref]unto [note]2[/note]Jesus, the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Author and [note]4[/note]Perfecter of our faith, who for the joy set before Him endured the [xref]c[/xref]cross, despising the [xref]d[/xref]shame, and has [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]sat down on the right hand of the [xref]f[/xref]throne of God.
verse.note: The Greek word translated [i]looking away unto[/i] denotes looking with undivided attention by turning away from every other object. The Hebrew believers had to look away from all the things in their environment, away from their old religion, Judaism, and its persecution, and away from all earthly things, that they might look unto Jesus, who is now seated on the right hand of the throne of God in the heavens.

The wonderful Jesus, who is enthroned in heaven and crowned with glory and honor ([link]2:9[/link]), is the greatest attraction in the universe. He is like an immense magnet, drawing all His seekers to Him. It is by being attracted by His charming beauty that we look away from all things other than Him. Without such a charming object, how could we look away from so many distracting things on this earth?

Or, Originator, Inaugurator, Leader, Pioneer, Forerunner. The same Greek word as in [link]2:10[/link]. All the overcoming saints in the Old Testament are only witnesses of faith, whereas Jesus is the Author of faith. He is the Originator, the Inaugurator, the source, and the cause of faith. In our natural man we have no believing ability. We do not have faith by ourselves. The faith by which we are saved is the precious faith that we have received from the Lord ([link]2 Pet. 1:1[/link]). When we look unto Jesus, He as the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]) transfuses us with Himself, with His believing element. Then, spontaneously, a kind of believing arises in our being, and we have the faith to believe in Him. This faith is not of ourselves but of Him who imparts Himself as the believing element into us that He may believe for us. Hence, He Himself is our faith. We live by Him as our faith; i.e., we live by His faith ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]), not by our own.[br][br]As the Author and the source of faith, Jesus is also the Leader, the Pioneer, and the Forerunner of faith. He cut the way of faith and, as the Forerunner, took the lead to pioneer it. Hence, He can carry us in His footsteps through the pathway of faith. As we look to Him as the Originator of faith in His life and in His path on earth, and as the Perfecter of faith in His glory and on His throne in heaven, He transfuses and even infuses us with the faith that He originated and perfected.

Or, Finisher, Completer. Jesus is also the Finisher, the Completer, of faith. He will finish what He originated. He will complete what He inaugurated. If we look to Him continually, He will finish and complete the faith that we need for the running of the heavenly race.

From [link]1:3[/link] this book points us continually to the Christ seated in heaven. In all his other Epistles Paul presents to us mainly the Christ who dwells in our spirit ([link]Rom. 8:10[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]) as the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]) to be our life and our everything. But in this book he points us particularly to the Christ who has sat down in heaven and who is of so many aspects, that He may care for us in every way. In Paul's other Epistles the indwelling Christ is versus our flesh, self, and natural man. In this book the heavenly Christ is contrasted to the earthly religion and all earthly things. To experience the indwelling Christ, we need to turn to our spirit and contact Him. To enjoy the heavenly Christ, we need to look away from all things on earth unto Him, who has sat down on the right hand of the throne of God. By His death and resurrection He accomplished everything that is needed by both God and man. Now in His ascension He is sitting in the heavens, in the person of the Son of God ([link]1:5[/link]) and the Son of Man ([link]2:6[/link]), in the person of God ([link]1:8[/link]) and man ([link]2:6[/link]), as the appointed Heir of all things ([link]1:2[/link]), the anointed One of God ([link]1:9[/link]), the Author of our salvation ([link]2:10[/link]), the Sanctifier ([link]2:11[/link]), the constant Succor ([link]2:16[/link]), the instant Helper ([link]4:16[/link]), the Apostle from God ([link]3:1[/link]), the High Priest ([link]2:17[/link]; [link]4:14[/link]; [link]7:26[/link]), the Minister of the true tabernacle ([link]8:2[/link]) with a more excellent ministry ([link]8:6[/link]), the surety and the Mediator of a better covenant ([link]7:22[/link]; [link]8:6[/link]; [link]12:24[/link]), the Executor of the new testament ([link]9:16-17[/link]), the Forerunner ([link]6:20[/link]), the Author and Perfecter of faith ([link]v. 2[/link]), and the great Shepherd of the sheep ([link]13:20[/link]). If we look to Him as such a wonderful and all-inclusive One, He will minister heaven, life, and strength to us, transfusing and infusing us with all that He is, that we may be able to run the heavenly race and live the heavenly life on earth. In this way He will carry us through all the lifelong pathway and lead and bring us into glory ([link]2:10[/link]).

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]compare Him who has endured such [xref]b[/xref]contradiction by sinners against Himself, so that you may not grow weary, [note]1[/note]fainting in your souls.
verse.note: Lit., becoming loosened.

verse.text: You have not yet resisted unto blood, struggling against [note]1[/note]sin,
verse.note: Sin here must refer to something evil in the sight of God that frustrates the believers and holds them back from the new covenant way, for it needs to be resisted, even unto blood.

verse.text: And you have completely forgotten the exhortation which reasons with you as with sons, [xref]a[/xref]"My son, do not regard lightly the [note]1[/note]discipline of the Lord, nor faint when reproved by Him;
verse.note: Or, chastening. So in [link]vv. 7[/link], [link]8[/link], and 11.

verse.text: For whom the Lord loves He [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]disciplines, and He [xref]b[/xref]scourges every son whom He receives."
verse.note: Or, chastens. So in [link]vv. 7[/link] and [link]10[/link].

verse.text: It is for [note]1[/note]discipline [i]that[/i] you endure; God deals with you as with [xref]a[/xref]sons. For what son is there whom the father does not discipline?
verse.note: From the viewpoint of God, the persecution from Judaism that the Hebrew believers suffered was a discipline, a chastening.

verse.text: But if you are without discipline, of which all [i]sons[/i] have become partakers, then you are illegitimate and not sons.

Furthermore we have had the fathers of our flesh as [note]1[/note]discipliners and we [xref]a[/xref]respected [i]them;[/i] shall we not much more be in subjection to the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Father of spirits and [xref]c[/xref]live?
verse.note: Or, chasteners.

[i]Father of spirits[/i] is contrasted with [i]fathers of our flesh.[/i] In regeneration we are born of God ([link]John 1:13[/link]) in our spirit ([link]John 3:6[/link]). Hence, God is the Father of (our) spirits.

verse.text: For they disciplined for a few days as it seemed good to them; but He, for what is profitable that we might partake of His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]holiness.
verse.note: Holiness is God's nature. To partake of God's holiness is to partake of His holy nature. It was common, unholy, for the Hebrew believers to remain in Judaism. They needed to be sanctified unto God's new covenant so that they could partake of God's holy nature. For that purpose, persecution was aroused to discipline them that they might be sanctified from the common.

verse.text: Now no discipline at the present time seems to be [i]a matter[/i] of joy, but of grief; but afterward it yields the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]peaceable fruit of righteousness to those who have been exercised by it.
verse.note: Peace is the fruit of righteousness ([link]Isa. 32:17[/link]). Holiness is the inward nature, whereas righteousness is the outward behavior. God's discipline helps the believers not only to partake of His holiness but also to be right with both God and man, that in such a situation of righteousness they may enjoy peace as a sweet fruit, a peaceable fruit of righteousness.

verse.text: Therefore [note]1[/note]set straight the [xref]a[/xref]hands which hang down and the paralyzed knees,
verse.note: Lit., set upright.

verse.text: And make [xref]a[/xref]straight [note]1[/note]paths for your feet, that what is lame may not be [note]2[/note]put out of joint but rather may be [xref]b[/xref]healed.
verse.note: The Christian life is not a matter of theoretical doctrines for the mind to think about. It must consist of practical paths for our feet to walk on. All the sound, healthy doctrines in the Bible are paths that can be walked on. This is especially true with the book of Hebrews. First, this book ministers to us the highest and healthiest doctrines concerning Christ and His new covenant. Then, based on the proper doctrines that it shows us, it charges us to run the race and make straight paths for our feet. The first section of this book ([link]1:1-10:18[/link]) deals with doctrines, and the second ([link]10:19-13:25[/link]) deals with the race and the paths.

Or, dislocated, wrenched. An alternate meaning, [i]turned aside,[/i] as in [link]1 Tim. 1:6[/link]; [link]5:15[/link]; and [link]2 Tim. 4:4[/link], does not match the antithesis that follows, "but rather may be healed," nor does it fit the context like the first meaning. The implication of the context is that the staggering Hebrew believers should abandon all appearance of the practices of Judaism (i.e., make straight paths) that they, the lame members (limbs) of the Body, might not fall into apostasy (i.e., not be put out of joint) but rather be brought fully into the new covenant way (i.e., be healed).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Pursue peace with all men and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sanctification, without which no one will see the Lord;
verse.note: With God, holiness is His holy nature; with us, holiness is our sanctification, our being separated unto God. (See note [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link].) The implication here is that while we are pursuing peace with all men, we must pay attention to the matter of sanctification before God. Our pursuing of peace with all men must be balanced by our sanctification before God, our being separated unto God, without which no one will see the Lord and have fellowship with Him.

verse.text: Looking carefully lest anyone [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fall away from the [xref]b[/xref]grace of God; lest any [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]root of bitterness springing up trouble [i]you,[/i] and through this many be [xref]d[/xref]defiled;
verse.note: The grace of God came to us through Christ ([link]John 1:14[/link], [link]17[/link]). Hence, it is also the grace of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]; [link]12:9[/link]). In our experience this grace is just Christ Himself ([link]Gal. 6:18[/link], cf. [link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]). When we fall from grace we are brought to nought, separated from Christ ([link]Gal. 5:4[/link]). Regarding this matter, Paul warned the churches of Galatia, which were in the same danger as the Hebrew believers, not to be separated from Christ by being turned aside to the law of the Jewish religion, lest they fall away from the grace of God, which is Christ Himself. We should not fall away from grace but should have grace ([link]v. 28[/link]), be confirmed by grace ([link]13:9[/link]), and stand in grace ([link]Rom. 5:2[/link]). Both Galatians and Hebrews close with the blessing of grace ([link]Gal. 6:18[/link]; [link]Heb. 13:25[/link]).

According to the implication of the context, the root of bitterness must be a Judaizer who would have caused the Hebrew believers to be turned aside from the grace of God to the rituals of Judaism and thus to defile themselves in the sight of God, neglecting the holiness of God.

verse.text: Lest there be any [xref]a[/xref]fornicator or profane person like [xref]b[/xref]Esau, who for one meal gave up his own [note]1[/note]birthright.
verse.note: Esau's birthright as the firstborn son of Isaac was the double portion of land, the priesthood, and the kingship. Because of Esau's profaneness in giving up his birthright, the double portion of land was given to Joseph ([link]1 Chron. 5:1-2[/link]), the priesthood was passed to Levi ([link]Deut. 33:8-10[/link]), and the kingship was assigned to Judah ([link]Gen. 49:10[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 5:2[/link]).[br][br]We Christians, born of God, are the firstfruits of His creatures ([link]James 1:18[/link]) that He has reaped in His creation. In that sense we are the firstborn sons of God. Hence, the church, composed of us, is called the church of the firstborn ([link]v. 23[/link]). As the firstborn sons of God, we have the birthright. This includes the inheritance of the earth ([link]2:5-6[/link]), the priesthood ([link]Rev. 20:6[/link]), and the kingship ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link]), which will be the main blessings in the coming kingdom and which the profane, world-loving-and-seeking Christians will lose at the Lord's coming back. Eventually, this birthright will be a reward given to the overcoming Christians in the millennial kingdom. Any worldly enjoyment, even one meal, could cause us to forfeit this birthright of ours. After such a serious warning, if the Hebrew believers had still preferred to indulge in "one meal" of their old religion, they would have missed the full enjoyment of Christ and would have lost the kingdom rest with all its blessings.[br][br]Esau was not the only one who lost his birthright ([link]Gen. 25:29-34[/link]); Reuben was another who lost the blessing of the birthright ([link]Gen. 49:3-4[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 5:1[/link]). Esau lost it because of his lust in eating. Reuben lost it because of the defilement of his lust. Both cases should be warnings to us. The word [i]lest there be any fornicator[/i] in this verse might have been written with Reuben as the background.[br][br]Actually, what we are privileged to enjoy in Christ is the foretaste of the blessings in the coming kingdom. The proper enjoyment of this foretaste will usher us into the full taste of the kingdom blessings. If we do not enjoy Christ today as our good land, as defined in note [link]9[sup]1[/sup][/link] of [link]ch. 4[/link], how can we enter into His rest in the kingdom and inherit the earth with Him? If we do not exercise our priesthood today to contact Him and prayerfully minister to Him, how can we fulfill our priestly duty in the kingdom? If we do not exercise our spirit with the God-given authority to rule our self, our flesh, our entire being, and the enemy with all his power of darkness today, how can we be Christ's co-kings and rule the nations with Him in His kingdom ([link]Rev. 2:26-27[/link])? Our enjoyment of Christ and the practice of the priesthood and kingship today are the preparation and qualification for our participating in Christ's kingdom tomorrow!

verse.text: For you know that also afterward, when he [xref]a[/xref]desired to inherit the blessing, he was rejected; for he found [note]1[/note]no place for repentance, even though he sought it with tears.
verse.note: [i]No place for repentance[/i] does not mean that Esau had no ground to repent; it means that he had no ground, no way, to reverse by repentance the result of what he had done.

verse.text: For you have not come forward to [i]a[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref][i]mountain[/i] which could be [xref]b[/xref]touched and which was set on [xref]c[/xref]fire, and to [xref]d[/xref]darkness and [xref]e[/xref]gloom and whirlwind,
verse.note: The things mentioned in [link]vv. 18-19[/link] are earthly and physical, signifying the side of the law, where everyone, including Moses, was in fear and trembling ([link]vv. 19-21[/link]).

verse.text: And to the [xref]a[/xref]sound of a trumpet and to the [xref]b[/xref]voice of words, [i]because of[/i] which those who heard [xref]c[/xref]entreated that no further word be spoken to them;
For they could not bear that which was being commanded: [xref]a[/xref]"If even a beast touch the mountain, it shall be stoned."
And so fearful was the sight, Moses said, "I am [xref]a[/xref]full of fear and trembling."

But you have come forward to [note]1[/note]Mount [xref]a[/xref]Zion and to the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]city of the [xref]c[/xref]living God, the [xref]d[/xref]heavenly Jerusalem; and to [xref]e[/xref]myriads of angels, to the [note]3[/note]universal gathering;
verse.note: The things mentioned in [link]vv. 22-24[/link] are heavenly and spiritual, in contrast to the earthly and physical things listed in [link]vv. 18-19[/link]. These things signify the side of grace, where both the firstborn and the spirits of righteous men are saved by grace. The people under the old covenant came to the side of the law, whereas we Christians, who are under the new covenant, come to the side of grace. Hence, we are not under the law but under grace ([link]Rom. 6:14[/link]). This portion of the word ([link]vv. 18-24[/link]), like [link]Gal. 4:21-31[/link], shows us that we are not under the bondage of the law but under the freedom of grace to be the heirs of the inheritance. This is our birthright! We should not give this up by falling away from grace ([link]v. 15[/link]), but should have grace ([link]v. 28[/link]). The things on the side of grace are heavenly, but not all are in heaven yet. A great number of the firstborn of the church are still on earth, while the spirits of righteous men, who are the Old Testament saints, are in Paradise, where Abraham is ([link]Luke 16:22-23[/link], [link]25-26[/link]) and where the Lord Jesus and the saved robber went after they died on the cross ([link]Luke 23:43[/link]).[br][br]None of the six items listed on the side of the law is pleasant. First, there is a mountain set on fire. Who would approach such a place? Then there are the darkness, the gloom, and the stormy whirlwind. Last, there are the terrifying sound of a trumpet and the solemn, warning voice of words. All these present a fearsome sight. On the side of grace, however, everything is pleasant. The eight items here can be considered four pairs. The elevated Mount Zion and the beautiful heavenly Jerusalem are the first pair, denoting God's habitation and the center of His universal administration. What a lovely place! The celebrating, jubilant angels, so closely related to the heirs of salvation to whom they minister ([link]1:14[/link]), and the blessed firstborn of the church form the second pair in the scene. What a joyful demonstration of an angelic gathering! They celebrate the participation by the human heirs of salvation, the church of the firstborn, in the blessings of the new covenant. God, the Judge of all, and the spirits of righteous men, the Old Testament saints (their bodies, not resurrected, were not worthy to be listed in this portion) are linked as the third pair, showing that God, being righteous, justifies the righteous saints of old because of their faith. The dear Lord Jesus, the Mediator of the new covenant, which is a better covenant, and His precious sprinkled blood, which speaks something better, compose the last pair, indicating that a better covenant was enacted with Jesus' better blood, that Jesus died and bequeathed this new covenant as a new testament to His believers, and that He is now the Mediator, the Executor, of this new testament, bringing about the full realization of all the blessed facts contained within it. What a pleasant scene! What a contrast to the scene on the side of the law, where no God, no Savior, and even no angels are mentioned! It is no wonder that not one saved person is seen there. In the scene of grace there is the justifying God, the Savior, who is the Mediator of His new testament, with His speaking blood, the ministering angels with the assembly (the church) of the saved ones, and the spirits of the justified saints. On the side of the law the scene ends with the terrifying sound of a trumpet and the warning words. On the side of grace the scene ends with a sympathizing Mediator and a vindicating speaking. After seeing such a contrast, who would be so foolish as to leave the side of grace and turn to the side of the law? All eight items on the side of grace are not only heavenly and spiritual but also eternal. Hence, even when heaven is shaken ([link]v. 26[/link]), these eight items that are eternal will still remain ([link]v. 27[/link]).
See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

Or, festal gathering. The Greek word means [i]universal gathering, whole[/i] or [i]full assembly,[/i] and is used to denote a group of people gathered to celebrate a public festival, such as the Olympic games. The entire new covenant age is a festival, and the myriads of angels, who are the ministering spirits rendering service to the heirs of salvation ([link]1:14[/link]) under the new covenant, are a universal gathering celebrating the marvelous festival of "so great a salvation" ([link]2:3[/link]), the greatest and most exciting "game" in the universe! The Lord's word in [link]Luke 15:7[/link], [link]10[/link], and [link]1 Pet. 1:12[/link] may indicate this.

verse.text: And to the [xref]a[/xref]church of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]firstborn, who have been [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]enrolled in the heavens; and to God, the [xref]d[/xref]Judge of all; and to the spirits of righteous men who have been made perfect;
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup][/link], par. 2.
Though the firstborn of the church are not yet in heaven, they are enrolled in the heavens.

verse.text: And to Jesus, the [xref]a[/xref]Mediator of a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]new covenant; and to the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]blood of [xref]d[/xref]sprinkling, which [note]3[/note]speaks something better than [i]that of[/i] [xref]e[/xref]Abel.
verse.note: The Greek word for [i]new[/i] here means [i]fresh, youthful,[/i] with respect to age, while the word for [i]new[/i] in [link]8:8[/link], [link]13[/link], and [link]9:15[/link] means [i]new, fresh,[/i] with respect to quality.

In this book the blood of Christ is particularly prominent and crucial. It is the blood of the eternal covenant ([link]13:20[/link]), with which the new and better covenant was enacted ([link]10:29[/link]). Through this blood Christ entered once for all into the Holy of Holies and obtained an eternal redemption for us ([link]9:12[/link]). By this blood Christ cleansed the heavens and all things in the heavens ([link]9:22-24[/link]). This blood sanctifies us ([link]13:12[/link]; [link]10:29[/link]), purifies our conscience to serve the living God ([link]9:14[/link]), and speaks something better for us than the blood of Abel ([link]v. 24[/link]). It is in this blood that we have boldness for entering the Holy of Holies ([link]10:19[/link]). We should not regard this blood common, like animal blood; if we do, we will suffer God's punishment ([link]10:29[/link]).

The blood of Christ not only redeems, sanctifies, and purifies; it also speaks. It is the speaking blood, speaking something better than the blood of Abel. Abel's blood speaks to God for accusation and vengeance ([link]Gen. 4:10-15[/link]), whereas Christ's blood speaks to God for forgiveness, justification, reconciliation, and redemption. Moreover, this precious blood speaks to God on our behalf, saying that by the blood (as unveiled in this book) the new covenant, which is eternal, has been enacted, and that in this new covenant God must give Himself and all His blessings to the believers in Christ who receive this covenant out of faith.

verse.text: See that you do not refuse Him who [xref]a[/xref]speaks, for if those did not [xref]b[/xref]escape who refused Him who warned [i]them[/i] upon the earth, much more we [i]shall not[/i] [xref]c[/xref][i]escape[/i] who turn away from Him who [i]warns[/i] from heaven,
Whose voice at that time [xref]a[/xref]shook the earth but now has promised, saying, [xref]b[/xref]"Yet once more I will shake not only the earth but also heaven."

And this [i]word,[/i] "Yet once more," shows clearly the [xref]a[/xref]removal of the things being shaken as being of things having been made, that the things which are not shaken may [xref]b[/xref]remain.

Therefore receiving an unshakable [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom, let us [note]2[/note]have [xref]b[/xref]grace, through which we may [xref]c[/xref]serve God [xref]d[/xref]well-pleasingly with piety and [xref]e[/xref]fear;
verse.note: The gospel that the New Testament has preached to us is the gospel of the kingdom ([link]Matt. 3:1-2[/link]; [link]4:17[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]10:7[/link]; [link]24:14[/link]). We were regenerated into the kingdom ([link]John 3:5[/link]) and were transferred into the kingdom ([link]Col. 1:13[/link]). Now we are in the kingdom ([link]Rev. 1:9[/link]), which today is the proper church life ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]). However, what we are in now and what is in the church today is the kingdom in its reality, whereas what will come with Christ's return in the future will be the kingdom in its manifestation.[br][br]The kingdom in its reality, or the reality of the kingdom, is an exercise and a discipline to us ([link]Matt. 5:3[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]7:21[/link]) in the church today whereas the kingdom in its manifestation, or the manifestation of the kingdom, will be a reward and an enjoyment to us ([link]Matt. 16:27[/link]; [link]25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]) in the millennial kingdom in the coming age. If we take the Spirit's exercise and God's discipline in the reality of the kingdom today, we will receive the Lord's reward and enter into the enjoyment of the coming Sabbath rest ([link]4:9[/link]) in the manifestation of the kingdom in the coming age; otherwise, we will miss the coming kingdom, we will not be rewarded with the manifestation of the kingdom at the Lord's coming back, we will have no right to enter into the glory of the kingdom to participate in Christ's reign in the millennial kingdom, and we will lose our birthright and therefore will be unable to inherit the earth in the coming age, to be the royal priests serving God and Christ in His manifested glory, and to be Christ's co-kings ruling all the nations with His divine authority ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]). To miss the coming kingdom and to forfeit our birthright does not mean that we will perish. It means that we will lose the reward but not our salvation. (See note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 10[/link].) We will suffer loss but still will be saved, yet so as through fire ([link]1 Cor. 3:14-15[/link]). This is the basic concept on which all five warnings in this book are given and with which they are all pervaded. All the negative points of these warnings are related to the suffering of the loss of the reward in the coming kingdom, whereas all the positive points are related to the reward and enjoyment of the kingdom. All seven epistles in [link]Rev. 2[/link] and [link book="Rev."]3[/link] conclude with this same concept — the reward of the kingdom or the loss of it. Only in light of this concept can we rightly understand and properly apply the word in [link]Matt. 5:20[/link]; [link]7:21-23[/link]; [link]16:24-27[/link]; [link]19:23-30[/link]; [link]24:46-51[/link]; [link]25:11-13[/link], [link]21[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]26-30[/link]; [link]Luke 12:42-48[/link]; [link]19:17[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]22-27[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:10[/link], [link]12[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:8[/link], [link]13-15[/link]; [link]4:5[/link]; [link]9:24-27[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:7-8[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:3[/link]; [link]4:1[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]11[/link]; [link]6:4-8[/link]; [link]10:26-31[/link], [link]35-39[/link]; [link]12:16-17[/link], [link]28-29[/link]; and [link]Rev. 2:7[/link], [link]10-11[/link], [link]17[/link], [link]26-27[/link]; [link]3:4-5[/link], [link]11-12[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]22:12[/link]. If we do not have this concept, the interpretation of these verses falls into either the extreme objectiveness of the Calvinist school or the extreme subjectiveness of the Arminian school. Neither of these schools recognizes the reward of the kingdom; even more, they do not see the suffering of the loss of the kingdom reward. Hence, both consider all the negative points in these verses as referring to perdition. The Calvinist school, believing in eternal salvation (i.e., that once a person is saved, he will never perish), regards all these negative points as applying to the perdition of false believers; while the Arminian school, believing that a saved person will perish if he falls, regards these points as applying to the perdition of believers who have fallen. But the complete revelation of the Bible shows that these negative points refer to the suffering of the loss of the kingdom reward. God's salvation is eternal; once we obtain it, we will never lose it ([link]John 10:28-29[/link]). But we may suffer the loss of the kingdom reward, even though we still will be saved ([link]1 Cor. 3:8[/link], [link]14-15[/link]). The warnings in Hebrews do not refer to the loss of eternal salvation but to the loss of the kingdom reward. The Hebrew believers had received the kingdom, but they risked losing the reward in the manifestation of the kingdom if they shrank back from the grace of God, from God's new covenant way. This was the writer's main concern in warning the staggering Hebrew believers.
Or, take. To have grace, especially for the Hebrew believers, was to remain in the new covenant to enjoy Christ.

verse.text: For our God is also a [note]1[/note]consuming [xref]a[/xref]fire.
verse.note: God is holy; holiness is His nature. Whatever does not correspond with His holy nature, He, as the consuming fire, will consume. If the Hebrew believers had turned aside to Judaism, which was common (unholy) in the sight of God, they would have become unholy, and the holy God as the consuming fire would consume them. God is not only righteous but also holy. To satisfy God's righteousness we need to be justified through the redemption of Christ. To meet the demands of His holiness we need to be sanctified, to be made holy by the heavenly, present, and living Christ. Romans stresses more the matter of justification ([link]Rom. 3:24[/link]) for God's righteousness ([link]Rom. 3:25-26[/link]), whereas Hebrews emphasizes more the matter of sanctification ([link]2:11[/link]; [link]10:10[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]29[/link]; [link]13:12[/link]) for God's holiness ([link]v. 14[/link]). For their sanctification, it was necessary that the Hebrew believers separate themselves from the unholy Judaism unto the holy God, who has fully expressed Himself in the Son under the new covenant; otherwise, they would have defiled themselves with their old, profane religion and would be dealt with by the holy God as the consuming fire. That would be fearsome ([link]10:31[/link])! It is no wonder that Paul was very concerned about the fear of the Lord ([link]2 Cor. 5:11[/link]).

verse.text: Let [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]brotherly love [note]2[/note]continue.
verse.note: As indicated by its content, this chapter was written with a view to a proper church life. Nearly everything mentioned here, such as brotherly love and hospitality, is for the church life, not only for the Christian life.
Or, remain.

verse.text: Do not forget [xref]a[/xref]hospitality, for through this some, without knowing it, have [xref]b[/xref]entertained angels.
[note]1[/note]Remember those who are imprisoned as bound with [i]them,[/i] those who are [xref]a[/xref]ill-treated as being yourselves also [i]likewise treated[/i] in body.
verse.note: This is to suffer with the suffering members of the Body of Christ, the church ([link]1 Cor. 12:26[/link]).

verse.text: [i]Let[/i] [note]1[/note]marriage [i]be held[/i] in honor [note]2[/note]among all, and the bed undefiled; for [xref]a[/xref]fornicators and adulterers God will [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]judge.
verse.note: In the church life, contact between brothers and sisters is unavoidable. Hence, to be protected from falling into defilement, we must hold marriage in honor and not behave loosely. This is a matter that seriously affects our birthright in God's economy. Reuben lost the birthright because of his defilement ([link]Gen. 49:3-4[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 5:1[/link]), and Joseph received it because of his purity ([link]1 Chron. 5:1[/link]; [link]Gen. 39:7-12[/link]; see note [link book="Heb."]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]). God will judge fornicators and adulterers, and the church too must judge them ([link]1 Cor. 5:1-2[/link], [link]11-13[/link]). Nothing damages the saints and the church life as much as this defilement.
Or, in every way.
This book concerns God's holiness. The holy God will not tolerate any defilement among us. He will judge His people ([link]10:30[/link]; [link]12:23[/link]).

verse.text: Let your way of life be without the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]love of money, being [xref]b[/xref]satisfied with the things which are at hand; for He Himself has said, [xref]c[/xref]"I shall by no means give you up, neither by any means shall I abandon you";
verse.note: Surely money lovers cannot enter into the reality of the church life. We should always be satisfied with what we have so that we cannot be distracted from the church life by mammon. Since we have the Lord as our Helper, we should be content and at peace that we may be kept fully in the enjoyment of the church life.

verse.text: So that being of good courage, we say, [xref]a[/xref]"The Lord is my Helper, and I will not fear. What shall man do to me?"

[note]1[/note]Remember the ones [xref]a[/xref]leading you, who have [xref]b[/xref]spoken to you the word of God; and considering the issue of their [xref]c[/xref]manner of life, [xref]d[/xref]imitate their faith.
verse.note: This is essential in the church life. The ministers of the word of God should have a manner of life that issues in an example of faith for the church members, the receivers of the word of God, to imitate. Then the church members not only will receive the word that the ministers minister but also will imitate the ministers' faith, which is expressed in their manner of life.[br][br][link]Verse 7[/link] is a continuation of [link]vv. 5-6[/link]. [i]Manner of life[/i] must refer to the living and behavior pursued by those ministers of the word of God, in which they had no love of money and were satisfied with what they had ([link]v. 5a[/link]). [i]Their faith[/i] must refer to the fact that they trusted in the Lord, their Helper, for their living ([link]vv. 5b-6[/link]). The word that they ministered and the life that they lived must have been entirely Christ, and their faith must have been the faith in Christ, of which Christ is both the Author and the Perfecter ([link]12:2[/link]). Such a manner of life and such a faith were surely worthy to be imitated by the believers, who received the word of God that the ministers ministered and who considered the issue of their manner of life.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Jesus Christ is the [xref]a[/xref]same yesterday and today, [i]yes,[/i] even forever.
verse.note: Christ, who is the word that the ministers of the word of God in [link]v. 7[/link] preached and taught, who is the life that they lived, and who is the Author and Perfecter of their faith, is perpetual, unchangeable, and unchanging. He remains the same forever ([link]1:11-12[/link]). There must not be another Jesus and another gospel preached in the church ([link]2 Cor. 11:4[/link]; [link]Gal. 1:8-9[/link]). For a true and steadfast church life, we must hold on to the Christ who is the same yesterday and today, and even forever, and must not be carried away by various strange teachings ([link]v. 9[/link]).

verse.text: Do not be [xref]a[/xref]carried away by [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]various strange teachings, for it is good for the heart to be [note]2[/note]confirmed by [xref]c[/xref]grace, not by the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]food [i]of sacrifices,[/i] by which those who walk were not profited.
verse.note: Various strange teachings are always used by Satan to cause dissension and even division in the church. Because of this, the apostle charged people not to teach different things ([link]1 Tim. 1:3[/link]). The various strange teachings must have been taught at that time by the Judaizers. The writer warned the Hebrew believers not to let the teachings of the Judaizers carry them away from the church life under the new covenant.

At that time, to be confirmed by grace was to remain in the new covenant to enjoy Christ as grace ([link]Gal. 5:4[/link]) and not to be carried away back to Judaism to participate in the eating of food (sacrifices) in the Jews' religious ceremonies.

The food mentioned here, being in contrast to grace, is the food used in the ceremonial observances of the old covenant ([link]9:10[/link]; [link]Col. 2:16[/link]). The Judaizers attempted to use such food to carry away the Hebrew believers from the enjoyment of grace, which is the participation in Christ in the new covenant.

verse.text: We have an [note]1[/note]altar from which they who are serving the tabernacle have no right to [xref]a[/xref]eat.
verse.note: This altar must be the cross on which the Lord Jesus offered Himself as the sacrifice for our sins ([link]10:12[/link]). According to the regulations concerning the offerings in the Old Testament, the sacrifice for sin, or the sin offering, the blood of which was brought into the Holy of Holies or the Holy Place to make expiation, afforded the offering priest or the offerer nothing to eat; the entire offering had to be burned up ([link]Lev. 4:2-12[/link]; [link]16:27[/link]; [link]6:30[/link]). Hence, those who serve the tabernacle have no right to eat from the altar of the sin offering (which in the New Testament fulfillment is the Lord's cross). [link]Verse 10[/link] is a strong argument against the Judaizers' using of food in their strange teachings to attempt to carry away the new covenant believers from the enjoyment of Christ. The Judaizers' emphasis was on the food that they enjoyed in their religious services. But the writer of this book argued that in the sin offering, the basic offering for yearly expiation ([link]Lev. 16[/link]), there was nothing for anyone to eat. With the sin offering, it is not a matter of eating it but a matter of receiving its efficacy. Now the real sin offering is Christ, who offered Himself to God for our sin and accomplished full redemption (better than expiation — see note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 9[/link]) for us that we may be brought into the enjoyment of God's grace in Him under the new covenant. What we need today is not to eat the food of the old covenant services but to receive the efficacy of Christ's offering and follow Him in the new covenant grace outside the camp, outside the Jewish religion.

verse.text: For the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bodies of those animals whose [xref]b[/xref]blood is brought into the [i]Holy of[/i] Holies for sin by the high priest are burned up outside the camp.
verse.note: The blood of the sin offering being brought into the Holy of Holies on the Day of Expiation to make expiation for the people and the bodies of the animals being burned up outside the camp ([link]Lev. 16:14-16[/link], [link]27[/link]) typify the blood of Christ, who is the real sin offering, being brought into the true Holy of Holies to accomplish redemption for us and the body of Christ being sacrificed for us outside the gate of the city of Jerusalem ([link]v. 12[/link]).

verse.text: Therefore also Jesus, that He might [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctify the people through His own [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]blood, suffered [xref]c[/xref]outside the [note]3[/note]gate.
verse.note: This book unveils to us that God's heavenly calling is to make us a holy people ([link]3:1[/link]), a people sanctified unto God. Christ is the Sanctifier ([link]2:11[/link]). He suffered death on the cross, shedding His blood, and entered the Holy of Holies with His blood ([link]9:12[/link]) that by the heavenly ministry ([link]8:2[/link], [link]6[/link]) of His heavenly priesthood ([link]7:26[/link]) He might be able to do the sanctifying work, and that we might enter within the veil by His blood to participate in Him as the heavenly Sanctifier. By participating in Him in this way, we are enabled to follow Him outside the camp by the sanctifying pathway of the cross. See notes [link]12[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]13[sup]1[/sup][/link].

The Lord's blood, through which He entered into the Holy of Holies ([link]9:12[/link]), opened the new and living way, enabling us to enter within the veil to enjoy Him in the heavens as the glorified One ([link]10:19-20[/link]); and His body, which was sacrificed for us on the cross, cut the narrow way of the cross, enabling us to go outside the camp to follow Him on earth as the suffering One ([link]v. 13[/link]).

This is the gate of the city of Jerusalem. The city signifies the earthly realm, while the camp signifies human organization. Together, the two signify one thing, the Jewish religion with its two aspects, the earthly and the human. Judaism is both earthly and human.

verse.text: Let us therefore go forth [xref]a[/xref]unto Him [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]outside the [note]2[/note]camp, bearing His [xref]c[/xref]reproach.
verse.note: [i]Outside the camp[/i] and [i]within the veil[/i] ([link]6:19[/link]) are two very striking points in this book. To enter within the veil means to enter into the Holy of Holies, where the Lord is enthroned in glory, and to go outside the camp means to come out of religion, whence the Lord was cast in rejection. This signifies that we must be in our spirit, where experientially the practical Holy of Holies is today, and outside religion, where the practical camp is today. The more we are in our spirit, enjoying the heavenly Christ, the more we will come outside the camp of religion, following the suffering Jesus. Being in our spirit to enjoy the glorified Christ enables us to come outside the camp of religion to follow the rejected Jesus. The more we remain in our spirit to contact the heavenly Christ, who is in glory, the more we will go forth outside the camp of religion unto the lowly Jesus to suffer with Him. By contacting Christ in the heavens and enjoying His glorification, we are energized to take the narrow pathway of the cross on earth and bear the reproach of Jesus. First, this book gives us a clear vision of the heavenly Christ and the heavenly Holy of Holies, and then it shows us how to walk on the earth in the pathway of the cross, i.e., how to go forth unto Jesus outside the camp, outside religion, bearing His reproach. Even Moses, after the children of Israel worshipped the golden calf ([link]Exo. 32[/link]), moved to a place outside the camp, where everyone who sought the Lord went to meet with him; for both the Lord's presence and the Lord's speaking were there ([link]Exo. 33:7-11[/link]). We must go outside the camp that we may enjoy the Lord's presence and hear His speaking. All these things are necessary for the practical and proper church life.[br][br]The Holy of Holies, the pathway of the cross (signified by the going forth unto Jesus outside the camp, bearing His reproach), and the kingdom are three crucial matters set forth in this book. The Holy of Holies with its rich supply enables us to take the narrow, difficult pathway of the cross, and the pathway of the cross ushers us into the kingdom in its manifestation that we may obtain the reward of glory.
See note [link]12[sup]3[/sup][/link].

verse.text: For we do not have here a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]remaining city, but [note]2[/note]we [xref]b[/xref]seek after the [xref]c[/xref]one to come.
verse.note: Or, permanent.
The writer of this book considered himself and his readers real river-crossing Hebrews, like the Patriarchs ([link]11:9-10[/link], [link]13-16[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Through Him then let us [xref]a[/xref]offer up a sacrifice of [xref]b[/xref]praise continually to God, that is, the [xref]c[/xref]fruit of lips [xref]d[/xref]confessing His name.
verse.note: [link]Verse 15[/link] is a continuation of [link]vv. 8-14[/link]. Since in the church life we enjoy the unchanging Christ as grace and follow Him outside religion, we should offer through Him spiritual sacrifices to God. First, in the church we should offer up through Him a sacrifice of praise to God continually. In the church He sings in us hymns of praise unto God the Father ([link]2:12[/link]). In the church we too should praise God the Father through Him. Eventually, in the church He and we, we and He, praise the Father together in the mingled spirit. He, as the life-giving Spirit, praises the Father in our spirit, and we, by our spirit, praise the Father in His Spirit. This is the best and highest sacrifice that we can offer to God through Him. This is greatly needed in the church meetings.

verse.text: But do not forget doing good and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sharing [i]with others,[/i] for with such [xref]b[/xref]sacrifices God is well pleased.
verse.note: Lit., fellowshipping. Doing good refers to giving, and fellowshipping refers to sharing, i.e., having fellowship in the needs of the saints. This kind of doing good and fellowshipping with others also are sacrifices that we should offer to God. These too are necessary for a proper church life. It is truly improper if in the church some needy saints are not well cared for and ministered to. This means that the fellowshipping with others is absent or inadequate.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Obey the ones [xref]a[/xref]leading you and [xref]b[/xref]submit to [i]them,[/i] for they [xref]c[/xref]watch over your souls as those who will render an account, that they may do this with joy and not groaning; for this would be unprofitable to you.
verse.note: This is vitally necessary in the church life.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Pray for us, for we are persuaded that we have a [xref]b[/xref]good conscience, desiring in all things to conduct ourselves honorably.
verse.note: Praying for the apostles is another aspect of the church life.

verse.text: And I exhort [i]you[/i] much more to do this that I may be restored to you more quickly.

Now the [xref]a[/xref]God of peace, He who [xref]b[/xref]brought up from the dead our Lord Jesus, the great [xref]c[/xref]Shepherd of the [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]sheep, in the [xref]e[/xref]blood of an [note]2[/note]eternal [xref]f[/xref]covenant,
verse.note: The sheep here are the flock, which is the church. This confirms the view that the things covered in this chapter, with the experience of the unchanging Christ as our sin offering, through whom we were redeemed, and as our great Shepherd, by whom we are now being fed, are all for the church life.

This book does not concern temporal things, such as the things of the old covenant, but eternal things, things that are beyond the limit of time and space, such as eternal salvation ([link]5:9[/link]), eternal judgment ([link]6:2[/link]), eternal redemption ([link]9:12[/link]), the eternal Spirit ([link]9:14[/link]), the eternal inheritance ([link]9:15[/link]), and the eternal covenant ([link]13:20[/link]).[br][br]The new covenant is not only a better covenant ([link]7:22[/link]; [link]8:6[/link]) but also an eternal covenant. It is eternally effective because of the eternal efficacy of Christ's blood, with which it was enacted ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]; [link]Luke 22:20[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Perfect you in every [xref]b[/xref]good work for the doing of His [xref]c[/xref]will, [note]1[/note]doing [xref]d[/xref]in us that which is well [xref]e[/xref]pleasing in His sight through Jesus Christ; to Him be the [xref]f[/xref]glory forever and ever. Amen.
verse.note: God is doing in us that which is well pleasing in His sight through Jesus Christ that we may be able to do His will. God works in us both the willing and the working for His good pleasure ([link]Phil. 2:13[/link]). From beginning to end this book presents to us a heavenly Christ. Only here, with the word "God...doing in us...through Jesus Christ," does this book imply the indwelling of Christ. It is through the indwelling Christ that God works in us so that we can do His will.

verse.text: Now I beseech you, brothers, [note]1[/note]bear with the word of this [xref]a[/xref]exhortation, for indeed I have written to you in few words.
verse.note: I.e., endure and receive. To bear with the word of the apostle also is needed in the church life ([link]Acts 2:42[/link]).

verse.text: Know that our brother [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Timothy has been released, with whom, if he comes soon, I will see you.
verse.note: The mentioning of Timothy in such an intimate way is a strong proof that this book was written by the apostle Paul. See [link]1 Tim. 1:2[/link] and [link]2 Tim. 1:2[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Greet all the ones [xref]a[/xref]leading you and all the saints. Those from Italy greet you.
verse.note: The greetings in this verse are a form of fellowship in the church and among the churches.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Grace be with you all. Amen.
verse.note: To realize and participate in all the things unveiled in this book, we need grace. To have grace ([link]12:28[/link]) we need to come forward to the throne of grace that we may find grace for timely help ([link]4:16[/link]). It is when we touch the throne of grace in the Holy of Holies through the exercise of our spirit that we enjoy the Spirit of grace ([link]10:29[/link]) and that our heart is confirmed by grace ([link]v. 9[/link]). By such an enjoyment of grace we run the race set before us ([link]12:1[/link]) that we may reach the goal of God's economy.
